PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I refer to allegations on last night's 7.30 Report that Telecom has made almost 700 tapes of phone conversations involving Casualties of Telecom, that is, persons seeking compensation from Telecom over failure to provide an adequate phone service resulting in substantial damage to their businesses. Is this figure correct? If not, what is the correct figure and on what basis does Telecom justify its actions? Is the minister also aware of an April 1993 internal Telecom document indicating that the telephone of yet another COT case member was tapped without his knowledge? What actions does the government propose to take in respect of these matters?

—I am aware of the background of the issues to which Senator Alston refers. He asked a question of me before, to which I provided an answer which was essentially based on a brief from the minister who was dealing with it directly. I am not aware of the details of the particular matter which he raised. I am sure the minister is and I will get a reply for Senator Alston as soon as I can.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I presume the minister did see a report in this morning's Australian Financial Review. If not, he is not being properly briefed. That report referred to this internal memo and I ask the minister to investigate whether in fact that document was not one of the documents released to Dawson's Pest and Weed Control pursuant to an FOI request. If that is the case, on what possible basis was it withheld from him?
—I will add that to the information about which I seek further advice from the minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade and relates to tariffs in Australia. I specifically ask the minister whether he is aware of recent media reports which suggest that the government is moving away from its support of a 5 per cent general tariff barrier after 1996? I also ask whether such reports are correct and does this mean that the government has reopened the tariff debate?

—Yesterday I did have the opportunity to address a forum of US pension fund managers whose investment funds collectively total something like $US4 trillion, so it was a group worth speaking to! In response to a question from some of them, I delivered a pretty simple and not at all subtle message about Australian tariff policy compared with the tariff policy of other countries, including the country from which they came. I am sure that all the professional fund managers in the audience fully understood the very clear message that I was giving them, but it does seem unfortunate that at least one journalist present did not understand it.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it clear in perhaps shorter and simpler words in case he or she wishes to correct his or her perception, because the words that I used, I thought, were clear and had a clear and unequivocal message. Those words do not change in any way the position of the government on this issue, which has been articulated by my predecessors, nor do they change in any way government policy on this matter. The government's policy is that it remains committed to lowering Australia's general tariff rate to five per cent by 1996. The policy that we had already developed and implemented put us in a very strong position in the tariff negotiations around the Uruguay Round and was part of and a contributor to—I do not want to exaggerate the extent of the contribution—achieving tariff cuts of more than 50 per cent from our major trading partners. This provides enormous potential benefits for Australia.

Although there are very big benefits to our primary industry sector from the Uruguay Round—for example, in the area of coal—it is also true to say there are big benefits for the manufacturing sector as a result of the major cuts in tariffs that were achieved. Australia is one of the few countries which is not having to make further adjustments to accommodate the requirements of the Uruguay Round, as our trading partners are, and from which we will benefit.

The point I was making fairly clearly and unequivocally to these guests to Australia was that the rest of the world is a long way behind Australia in this matter. It is not an issue about which we have any intention, or feel under the slightest pressure, to move any further in terms of the reasonable response to the requirements of the Uruguay Round or the activities of our trading partners; and unless and until we get to a situation where the international community catches up with the position we have achieved, there is no likelihood we will go further.

The only way anything could possibly have been interpreted as a qualification of what I thought was a very straightforward position—and what I thought was very clear, and I think as reported is clear, but for some reason the interpretation in the newspaper is not—was that if in some unforeseeable future circumstance in the next round of multilateral negotiations the whole trade debate has moved on to new parameters, that is something Australia will need to look at then.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, as the farmers' new-found friend, what he is doing to recover the lost equity belonging to the wheat farmers in the 1987-88 and 1989-90 wheat pools due to the freezing of Iraqi assets in the United States. —I am not aware of the detail of that particular problem, although I am aware of it in general terms because Senator Panizza has raised the problem in the Senate on previous occasions. I have had the opportunity in the last two weeks of meeting with the Australian Wheat Board and discussing with it in some detail—in terms of my being a friend of the farmers, which indeed I am—the major item of interest to me at the moment, which is the prospect for the market for the entire yield. As Senator Panizza knows full well, the wheat industry, along with dairying, beef and a number of other primary industries, is looking far more positive at the moment in terms of both the harvest and markets than it has for some significant time. I am in the happy position of being able to tell Senator Panizza something which, as one of many primary producers who are active members of the coalition in parliament today, he already knows, and that is that prospects for the wheat industry generally are looking positive.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the detailed matter of the Iraqi assets and so on being frozen, I do not have any information on the current situation. So I cannot advance Senator Panizza any more information beyond that available when he raised the matter before. I will obtain a detailed answer for him as soon as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business as the Minister responsible for the Australian Customs Service. Earlier today the minister released the report of the independent review into the Australian Customs Service which was headed by Frank Conroy. Is the minister able to provide any information on the major recommendations of the report and its implications for the Customs Service? Secondly, what benefit does the minister expect from this important review?

—Earlier today, as honourable senators will be aware, I circulated to all members of parliament and to the press a copy of the Conroy review of Customs, The turning point, a copy of which I will table at the end of question time. I thank Mr Conroy, Mr Ian Macphee, Ms Susan Ryan and members of the secretariat for their contribution to preparing the report over the past seven months. It was a very wide-ranging report in accordance with the wide terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: The report deals with relations with industry, the public and government agencies. The broad themes of the report are: the need for Customs to establish closer links with industry in Australia; the value of good public administration; and the better use of technology. I have already announced that I have accepted the broad thrust of the report, which can be best summed up as trying to achieve a cultural change in the operation of Customs. That would be well recognised by members on both sides of the parliament who have been involved with such issues as the Midford report. All of those reports dealt with the need for a change in the culture of Customs, its style of operation and how it relates to the community.

There are many recommendations, a number of which will quite clearly be controversial. I will ask the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development in consultation with Customs, the PSU and other interested parties to prepare a considered report on each of the recommendations, which I hope to take to cabinet within about six to eight weeks. I will then make further announcements about the outcome of those recommendations.

This morning, I had the opportunity to speak in Canberra to the senior management of Customs and to several hundred of its staff and to explain my view about the implementation process and preparation of the cabinet submission. I told them that I was sympathetic to the broad thrust of the report. Many people in Customs welcome this opportunity to be involved. I emphasised the need that, for the successful implementation of this report, it must be driven from the ground up within Customs as much from the top down to get the needed changes, which I think all sides of parliament would support.

I also announced today that the Comptroller-General of Customs, Mr Frank Kelly, has resigned from the position. I have recommended the appointment of the Deputy Comptroller-General, Mr Chris Doogan, to the position of Acting Comptroller-General. I made it clear to Mr Doogan and to others in the service that this is an acting position and that, as we develop the cabinet submission, we will look at the arrangements for the appointment of a new chief executive, a post for which he and other senior officers would be eligible to apply. But that will come after we make decisions in cabinet about what structure we want for Customs, not before.

I want to place on record that Mr Kelly was a long-time member of the Customs Service and, despite the criticisms that some members of parliament have raised, he has done a number of things that have been good for the Customs Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is last Friday's decision by the United Nations Security Council to cut the size of the military operation in Somalia going to further exacerbate tension and civil disorder in that country? Indeed, has it already done so? Was the United Nations forced, in part, to reduce its involvement in Somalia because of continuing financial difficulties and the failure of member states to pay their dues to the UN? Which states in particular are not fulfilling their financial obligations to the United Nations, and how can the Australian government encourage those countries to meet those international obligations?

—On Friday, 4 February the Security Council, in resolution 897, did adopt a resolution authorising a reduction in UNOSOM force levels to no more than 22,000 personnel. That is a reduction from the some 28,000 that have been there during the course of the UNOSOM operation. It does represent a significant draw down. I add that it may well be in practice that the draw down will be to rather fewer numbers than that, perhaps in the order of 16,000 rather than the 22,000 that is here provided for. In keeping with this reduced capacity, the resolution limits UNOSOM's security mandate to protecting major ports, airports and essential infrastructure, and safeguarding lines of communication for relief and reconstruction activities.

PARA.TAB: The resolution abandons further attempts by UNOSOM to forcibly disarm the Somali factions, although there is still a retention of a chapter VII enforcement mandate as well as a chapter VI mandate to cope with the reality that if the UN forces are put under military pressure, they may well need to respond in a way that goes beyond just a simple chapter VI self-defence. That lesson has been learned in the initial UNOSOM operation, and it has been retained here in that form.

I think it is a fair judgment that the UN resolution is at least partly a response to some of the financial pressure that is being experienced by the UN at the moment. Probably more than that, however, it is a response by donor countries to the perception that there is simply no necessity—or strong case any longer to be made—for a very strong, active, aggressive military presence to be sustained in Somalia on the scale that was there in the earlier stages of the UNOSOM operations.

However, there is a question that does arise, particularly if the draw down is of the order of 15,000 or 16,000 rather than 22,000, as to whether the UN will have a sufficiently substantial presence in enough parts of the country other than Mogadishu, Kismayu and Baidoa—and two or three other areas of that kind—to be able to effectively perform its function. That is something that we have a pretty close interest in with Australian personnel still in the country and, as a result, we will be watching it very closely.

One of the useful things about the resolution last week is that it does emphasise the need for the Somalis themselves to assume the principal responsibility for their national reconciliation process. It underlines the importance to that political process of developing the fragile Somali police, judicial and penal systems, all of which are very important to the recreation of some kind of viable governmental infrastructure for the country. So I think the resolution is positive and forward looking in those ways. Moreover, it reaffirms quite explicitly the objective that the mission cease completely by March 1995. It is useful to set an end date in that way.

As to the financial situation of the UN, 15 major contributors to the UN had amounts totalling $345 million owing to the regular budget at last count at the end of the year, including contributions outstanding from prior years. The United States, Japan, Germany, the Russian Federation, Italy, Spain, the Ukraine, Brazil and Belgium had amounts outstanding totalling $860 million for peacekeeping contributions. So there is a very substantial shortfall financially for the UN. Some of that will be fixed naturally in the course of the year. Other parts of it are a bit more long standing.

The United States has been one of the main problem countries because it is such a large percentage donor for the UN system. I do not think that is the fault of the present administration which is committed to maintaining its role in this respect. There is certainly a lot of continuing hostility amongst members of the US Congress, and they are the ones who have to appropriate the resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. Given that the financial situation obviously is not what it ought to be, does the minister believe that this has also impacted on the situation in Bosnia?

—I do not honestly think that financial considerations are the immediate cause of the reluctance of the international community to get itself more substantially involved in Bosnia. I think it is a recognition that the scale of the necessary intervention, if it really were to take place in a way that would involve a complete military occupancy of the country and the complete imposition of a military solution, would be so massive that it would not only be a matter of financial resources being hard to find, but the will, the commitment and the capacity simply would not be there from donor countries.

PARA.TAB: It is often speculated that the order of magnitude of the resources needed in Bosnia to do a military job properly on the ground would be between 400,000 and 500,000 personnel. The notion of being able to get there simply by air strikes is not one that has commended itself hitherto, anyway, to those who have been responsible for making judgments about the military outcome in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Yesterday, the minister attended the signing of a contract between the Civil Aviation Authority and Thomson CSF for the supply of a new air navigation system for Australia. Could the minister explain the significance of this contract for the development of greater export opportunities for Australia?

—I was delighted to be present yesterday at the official signing between Australia's Civil Aviation Authority and the French radar giant, Thomson CSF, of a contract worth $A176 million for the implementation of Australia's first fully integrated air traffic management system. It will be a system that will ensure that air travellers in Australia fly safely well into the 21st century.

PARA.TAB: I was particularly delighted to sign as part of a general signing ceremony the Australian industry involvement deed between the Commonwealth of Australia and Thomson CSF. The deed is critical to the further development of the Australian air systems industry, which has already proved itself as a world class industry by winning substantial export dollars for this country in markets overseas.

The deed commits Thomson to substantial research and development activity in Australia and to provide opportunities here as well. Specifically, Thomson is committed to facilitating exports of $550 million through to the year 2000. The agreement will as well support the creation of 800 new jobs in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia and, importantly—and given the nature of this debate, I think quite significantly—Thomson has undertaken to establish its regional headquarters for Asia and the Pacific in Australia.

The Australian companies which will benefit from this—colloquially known as the TAAATS contract—include AWA, which has, I think, the best voice switching technology in the world and which supplies sophisticated communications products as well; Adacel, a supplier of air traffic simulation computer software; Lochard Environmental Systems, already a world leader in airport noise and flight traffic monitoring systems; and the John Holland construction company.

The contract will enable these companies and others to take advantage of integration in the marketing efforts of one of the world's leading air traffic control companies. They will also be able to access technology systems at the leading edge of development and to participate in a wider spread of projects by virtue of their association with this dominant company.

Government purchasing has played a role here. It should play an important role in the development of Australian industry by providing local reference sites for companies that wish to pursue business offshore and important development opportunities at the best competitive price and quality for the Australian taxpayer. It is a good outcome for all concerned in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. In light of the comments by the Commonwealth Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, that he fears the government is intent on using legal avenues to thwart the necessary role of the audit office in scrutinising government operations, can the minister give the Senate a categorical assurance that, firstly, Mr Taylor's position as Commonwealth Auditor-General has the total confidence and support of the government and, secondly, that the government will cease henceforth in all cases from using legal advice and related tactics to circumvent the Auditor-General's open access to all documentation held by government departments?

—This is a trivial question because it asks the government to re-affirm one of the quite important posts of independence in the whole constellation of government effort, and that is the office of the auditor. One does respect his independence and statutory responsibility to report openly and fairly.

PARA.TAB: The question then goes on to play a political game and say that all relevant documents should be made available to the auditor. It is my experience and understanding that that is the case of government departments. But the most celebrated case, which this question does not refer to, which is subject to some controversy, and which was the subject of a series of questions in this chamber yesterday, concerns sporting grants. The issue between the auditor and the minister at that time, where the minister sought legal advice, was where the auditor sought, as I understand it, documentations held privately by the minister which were not departmental documentations.

I am not sure of the outcome of that legal advice, but it seems to me it does not go to the answer of the question. One ought to identify this issue, even though it was not the subject of the direct question, because a blurring of this particular line of demarcation is tantamount to trying to mount yet another smear in the case of the sports grants affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the farmers' friend, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Given the increasing awareness in the community of the massive problems caused by land degradation and water pollution, can the minister advise what steps are currently being taken under the Landcare program to further address these problems?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for this very timely question. Landcare is much appreciated by the farming community and, indeed, until today in question time I thought it enjoyed bipartisan support. The time has arrived for community groups, which are the driving force of the Landcare movement, to apply for funding for the next financial year in terms of the invaluable programs and cooperation with the primary industry sector that the Landcare movement is achieving in Australia. I would certainly urge all community groups that are involved in Landcare to apply.

PARA.TAB: The growth of the Landcare movement in Australia is proof in itself of its success. In 1985 there were 75 Landcare groups around Australia. That has grown to 1,900 groups today. Indeed, I am sure that other senators would be familiar, as I am, with the valuable work that is being done by Landcare in their own states. In the Northern Territory, for example, Landcare is directly involved in the elimination of mimosa pigra from coastal plains. It is involved in the difficult question of the supply of water to Aboriginal and remote communities in the Northern Territory, rangeland soil degradation and so on, and I am sure many similar projects are being conducted by Landcare elsewhere in Australia.

I think the most encouraging thing about the growth of the movement is that nearly 30 per cent of the nation's farmers are now members of Landcare groups and a growing number of companies are involved. There is increasing support from the corporate sector as the success of this movement in getting the score on the board is shown more and more. The program, as I said before, has received bipartisan support and I hope it will continue to do so.

Community Landcare is designed to encourage and assist local groups and land-holders to identify problems and to take appropriate action to fix them. Together with Landcare Australia's Don Burke, I call on those community groups to get their funding proposals to the government as quickly as possible so that they can be considered. Last year the federal government provided $12.5 million to fund these groups across Australia. This year the program will again gain support for these projects to at least the same level. Applications for grants for the next financial year will close on 31 March and new projects will begin—

TALK.START.PARA: —Show a bit of enthusiasm, Bob!
—That is just about the right tone.

—That is dead right. I think it is a suitably serious topic. Is Senator Kemp a Titanic survivor or is he a canoe paddler? Which one is he? New projects will begin at the beginning of the financial year. I assure the Senate that the federal government will do everything it can to continue to support this very successful partnership between the corporate sector, the farming community and the local communities in Australia in the invaluable work that Landcare Australia is doing.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in his own capacity and that of Minister representing the Minister for Resources. What will be the effect on our balance of payments for 1993-94 of the recent reduction in export coal prices, coupled with the reduced tonnage to Japan and the increased value of the Australian dollar? Further, what is the government doing to avert the 24-hour rolling strikes which commenced today, which cannot have any impact on the monetary exchange rates, the world oversupply of coking coal or the Japanese steel production, and which can only further harm our major export industry?

—I do not think that industrial action that is currently threatened will achieve anything. In fact, in my view, it will certainly undermine the very considerable benefits that have been assisted by the union movement in the mining sector in Australia in the efficiencies that have been gained in the Australian mining industry. I can—and I think any reasonable person can—understand the sense of frustration in the work force at the decline in prices. There has been a significant downturn in the Japanese steel industry. It is a situation where the international market has set the price. We are not in a position to do much about that.

PARA.TAB: I have seen the perennial subject raised of establishing national coal boards and so on, but the principal reason behind the downturn in the price is the price that has been set by the Canadian suppliers of coking coal. The most important thing for the Australian negotiators, in my view—and they achieved it—was to be able to match that price in order to maintain Australia's market share in Japan. Disappointing as the outcome was in terms of price, I do understand the legitimate concern of the workers in the industry about the price of the product that they produce—

TALK.START.PARA: —Coming down hard on both sides, aren't you?

—They produce it; they are the ones that risk their necks digging it out of the ground. I know that the workers in any industry are a total irrelevancy as far as the coalition is concerned, and will continue to be so, but I do understand that people who work in industry are concerned about the price that is gained for the product they produce with their sweat. I understand that; those opposite do not. The key point about these negotiations, and it is an important point, is that the Australian negotiators were able to maintain the share of the market that is so important for Australia in what, hopefully, will be a cyclical decrease in the price of coal. I think that has been the most important result.

PARA.TAB: I know that the Minister for Resources, who is the minister responsible for the coal industry, has contacted the union leadership in Australia and expressed the government's concern about industrial action which, as I said, in the government's view not only will achieve nothing but will potentially undermine the union movement's contribution to the great efficiency gains that have been made in this industry.

With regard to the detailed question of the potential impact—I stress it would be only a potential impact—of the drop in price of that particular commodity on our balance of payments, I do not have that figure, but I will get what will have to be a hypothetical figure at this stage and provide it to Senator Parer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and it concerns the commitment Mr Keating made, following the passage of the Native Title Bill, that there would be full consultation with Aboriginal people leading up to the formulation of a social justice package this year. First, what consultation has taken place in the past six weeks on the social justice package; secondly, what is the government's time line and scope for the consultation and formulation of the package; thirdly, is the social justice package to form part of the federal budget formulation; and, fourthly, does the government envisage that the social justice package will concentrate on health, education and land acquisition issues, or will it also encompass other more structural issues such as the management of land and resources?

—I have not been briefed on matters of detail relating to that; I have not been personally involved in it. I will seek detailed answers and give them to Senator Chamarette as soon as possible. We do retain our commitment to the social justice package. Obviously it is one of the major things to be addressed in a budget context, but as to what precisely I can say at this stage about details of consultations past, present and future, time lines and content, I will need to check with the Prime Minister. If Senator Chamarette can hold her horses, she will get an answer very soon.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the minister has found that out, will he also explain why it is that key Aboriginal organisations around Australia are unaware of any consultation process or the time frame for this process?
—I will respond to all aspects of Senator Chamarette's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I refer the minister to his recent comments that the era of direct handouts to industry has come to an end, and I congratulate him on that attitude. However, I ask, firstly, whether he agrees with the recent article by Steve Burrell in the Australian Financial Review in which the suggestion is made that the industry portfolio is therefore irrelevant; and, secondly, whether he agrees with the Burrell suggestion that the industry portfolio should now see itself as a major innovator in ridding the economy of impediments to business competitiveness, or whether he now sees the department as adopting a more interventionist role within Australian industry and retreating to the old business of trying to pick winners?

—This question falls into the category of a fishing expedition, and it is one that will be met with an outcome, but not today. This government, over the past 11 years of our administration, has presided over an industry policy which has seen manufacturing exports from this country boom and a resurgence at the same time as there has been a restructuring of the industry base in this country. We now have, according to the competitiveness index, a much more competitive economy able to cut its way in the international marketplace. I would hope to continue in that tradition of industry policy development and implementation to ensure that the gains that have been made through that restructuring and the increases in our competitiveness continue.

PARA.TAB: The questions I am asked today really invite the answer that I gave to a question asked last week by Senator Spindler—that is, I will neither confirm nor deny my approach to industry policy at this stage. I am still working on that. As foreshadowed, I will put down a major statement on industry policy in late April or early May, and that will point the directions of industry policy for this country for the next 10 years.

But in that policy some things will remain consistent. This government embarked upon a major program of micro-economic reform and the removal of impediments to industry. In my consultations with industry, both in the last week or so and over the last year in my role as Minister for Trade, one of those impediments constantly raised is the issue of micro-economic reform. I think that our record is in fact one of tackling micro-economic reform head-on and making significant gain. But one should never rest on one's laurels; there is always a continuing improvement to be made.

One of the points that industry makes to me constantly is that while the federal government has embarked on micro-economic reform and deserves marks and recognition for what it has done, the area of micro-economic reform that is lagging and needs most attention now is in the constitutional purview of the states. State micro-economic reform under the control of state governments is a major issue in ensuring that the economy of this country is more competitive in the international marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Blame it on the states!

—I will not rise to the bait by biting back at the comments made about the states. I would like to see a partnership between the Commonwealth and the states in tackling these very serious problems. I have said before that we can no longer look upon our industry base as focusing on a local market within our own region or, indeed, the domestic Australian market; we ought to look upon industry policy as focusing on the global marketplace because that is where Australian companies are benchmarking themselves. That is where their market and their measure of competitiveness is. I would hope to bring that approach to industry policy formulation as well and, as I say, continue in the tradition of restructuring and reform that has gone on in this government over the 11 years of office to ensure that our industry remains and becomes more competitive in the world marketplace.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. I refer to the position paper on women's health which was recently released by the Australian Medical Association and which called for more specific research on women's health needs. Can the minister tell the Senate what moves are being made to increase the amount of research which is specific to women's health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Zakharov for this question. I was very pleased on Saturday last to address the AMA forum which followed the release of its position paper on women's health. I was even more pleased, indeed slightly stunned, to read that the AMA endorsed the federal government's national women's health policy. Let me read to the Senate the endorsement because it really marks a new era with the AMA:

ANSWER.PARA: The AMA supports the goals of the Australian Government National Women's Health Policy to improve the health and well being of all Australian women.

It was interesting to note that Brendan Nelson, who launched that paper, made the comment himself—very disparaging of the AMA—that it was very late for the AMA to have a view about women's health policy for the public arena. He said that 1994 was a very late year for this to happen. I was pleased to remind Brendan Nelson that 1994 is the centenary of the women's vote in South Australia, which I think means the AMA is about 100 years behind.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make it clear, too, that while the AMA may indeed be endorsing the government's policy, we do not endorse all of the AMA's policies. This government has had a far reaching commitment to women's health, and included in that was its promise at the last election to establish the first ever specific to women longitudinal study in women's health research. I am pleased to say that that policy and that election promise is a promise kept.

Today I have announced the advisory committee that will advise me on the design of that longitudinal study. It is the first ever, and I think we have a great opportunity to put in place very significant new research for Australian women. It is very important to note that that committee will be chaired by Dr Heather Mitchell, the Medical Director of the Victorian Cervical Cytology Registry and the Victorian Breast Screening Program Registry. The committee, including representation from the nursing profession, from the Public Health Association, from the Consumer Health Forum and from the public health area, will be addressing questions such as deficiencies or gaps in current research and data, any gender bias in research allocation and the health implications in particular to women's social roles. We cannot possibly overlook the status of Aboriginal women's health as well as the health of women from non-English speaking backgrounds.

Not too long ago I received from a significant medical authority a little dial-your-own health data kit which enables people to check what their blood pressure, pulse rate and weight should be and so on. But I noticed that it was put together from data actually taken from 150,000 men and extrapolated for women.

I think the time has come for us to have health data and research data about women for women—not the adaptation of data about men. We know that we simply do not have a lot of basic data about women. We also do not have specific women's health data. Studies of men will provide no information about menopause or menstruation and, importantly, studies by men have actually ignored the evidence of women. So I am delighted that we now have established this advisory committee, and this is the first stage in establishing this longitudinal study. The importance of women's health research and women's health data cannot be overstated. Once that data is given to the government, we will be able to make sure our policies are targeted to most appropriately meet the continuing needs of women's health.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. When was the minister first asked to use his powers under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act to halt the development of the Broome Crocodile Farm? By whom was he asked to intervene?
—I will provide—
—He is looking for his brief!

—Absolutely; I am not across this issue at all. I cannot do everything. I am happy to provide Senator Ellison with the information that has been given to me by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. It appears from that information that the agency that actually contacted the minister—I think that is what Senator Ellison is seeking—was the Kimberley Land Council.
—That would be right.

—The Kimberley Land Council actually does represent Aboriginal people. The council was acting on behalf of the community directly involved in the project. That application was received by the minister on 31 January this year. With respect to the crocodile farm at Broome, the application sought protection under sections 9 and 10 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act. On 4 February, the minister used the powers that he has under that act to stop work on the site. —My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government, relates to the question I asked of the minister last Thursday—which he refused to answer—regarding the doubling of Pasminco's deadline to dump waste. Did the minister refuse to answer that question because the decision was unjustifiable and he was too embarrassed? Should Australia be embarrassed by being the only signatory to the London Dumping Convention which will continue to dump industrial waste into the ocean after 1995 in contravention of the ban? Is the minister concerned that Australia's declaration of non-acceptance of the industrial ban might result in other countries taking a similar position in relation to the radioactive waste ban which he worked so hard to achieve?

—No, Mr President, the reason I declined to answer Senator Bell's question last week was not any imminent or actual embarrassment; it was that Mrs Kelly was making a full statement about an hour or so afterwards—which she duly did. I think that has explained the basis of the government's decision. I am not concerned about the international ramifications of this because the particular extension for two years beyond the phase-out period of 1995 that we are seeking to enable Pasminco to continue to dump industrial waste at sea—as it has been doing for the last 20 years—is one that is provided for within the terms of the London Dumping Convention, of which we are an enthusiastic member.

PARA.TAB: The convention enables parties to it to, within a 100-day period expiring on 18 February, make any declaration they wish about limiting the scope of the convention to them. Once such a declaration is made, it is absolutely binding and it cannot be amended so as to upgrade it or extend it in the future. The declaration that we propose to make is one that is quite narrow and finite in scope and operation; namely to extend the period to 1997 rather than meet the objective date of 1995.

The reason why we sought that extension is that the industrial processes that are presently being developed to enable jarosite not to be produced at all as a waste residue from zinc production are not yet at a stage where we can be confident that the 1995 deadline would be met; in which case the only other alternative—apart from the company going out of business—would be for the company to adopt a landfill operation for some 200,000 tonnes of jarosite a year. This, of course, would raise its own environmental problems about which Tasmanians and others in the environmental movement have been equally upset. There are no easy options. It is either a matter of closing the plant and putting hundreds of people out of work in what is one of Tasmania's major industries, or creating another kind of environmental problem, or continuing for another two years what has been done for the last 20 years, and which has not caused any environmental damage at all.

The truth of the matter is that, although it is desirable to avoid dumping industrial waste at sea, and although it is desirable to avoid dumping this particular iron compound, jarosite, with its very small amounts of lead, arsenic and cadmium that are associated with it, there is no evidence whatsoever that the dumping that has occurred over the last 20 years has caused any environmental damage at all, given the dispersion of the waste in question that is involved with this kind of dumping process, and the way in which it reduces to levels and amounts and quantities which are not a cause for serious alarm.

As to other countries: we are only aware at this stage of one other country—Russia—that is likely to seek any kind of similar exemption, and that is not in relation to industrial waste, but radioactive waste. On any view, there is a very substantial difference in character between the kind of industrial waste we are talking about here and the radioactive waste which has generated so much concern from us and from other countries in the South Pacific and elsewhere around the world. It is a purely temporary extension of the dumping that is involved. It is squarely within the terms of the convention. Our position on this is well understood by the other parties to the convention. There is a heap of other problems facing us if we go down any other route but this one. For all these reasons, it is a decision that I think makes a great deal of sense, and I hope it will be understood as such.

From 1987 through to 1992 the matter was the subject of a good deal of negotiation with local Aboriginal people, the Department of Land Administration and the Aboriginal sites department. In June 1992 an agreement was signed by Mr Douglas with the chairperson of the Yawaru Aboriginal Corporation for the development of a crocodile farm.

PARA.TAB: The then minister for Aboriginal affairs—bearing in mind that was a Labor state government at that time—had indicated his consent to the development provided that the Yawaru people were in agreement. The Kimberley Land Council commissioned a report which resulted in the reconsideration of the matter from December 1992 until July 1993. It was not until July 1993 that the minister finally gave consent for lease for the crocodile farm provided that certain parts of it were excised so as to take into account certain initiation tracts which the local Aboriginal people used.

At that stage Mr Douglas had expended a great deal of money and time in bringing this development to fruition. Subsequently several applications were made in the Federal Court and the Supreme Court of Western Australia. As I understand it, four attempts were made to gain injunctions to stop this development. The relevance of my supplementary question was that Western Australia had another controversial development regarding the Aboriginal community, namely, the Swan Brewery site. I am advised by Mr Douglas that he employs eight locals. He intends to work with local Aborigines and train them in crocodile farming. He could face great financial loss and the town could lose a possible $500,000 in exports per annum. To me, that is a most unsatisfactory state of affairs. Although the courts have decided that this development can go ahead, this federal minister for Aboriginal affairs is going to ride roughshod over the rights of small businessmen and state interests.

My question related, firstly, to allegations on the 7.30 Report and, secondly, to the contents of an internal Telecom document which was described in today's Australian Financial Review.

PARA.TAB: After question time, Senator McMullan came back and said that he had been advised by minister Lee's office that the answer he had given to my question last week still stood. That in fact had nothing to do with either the 7.30 Report or this internal Telecom document, the contents of which became publicly known only this morning. Therefore, I have to say that it is a very inauspicious debut by the minister. I would have thought that, at the very least, he would want to contemplate the question that Senator McMullan knew nothing about and come back with a considered answer tomorrow. But, instead, he has rushed in to give an answer which effectively seems to suggest that he has not even paid attention to the subject matter of today's question.

To the extent that he was trying to say that any matters that were raised today are to be treated as having been disclosed by Mr Blount, the managing director of Telecom, to the minister in mid-January, I take that as a matter of some significance. I hope that it is not simply an inference that one is able to draw because of the haste with which the answer was given. I would therefore invite the ministers to make clear in this chamber whether it is being said that the allegation on last night's 7.30 Report that almost 700 tapes of phone conversations involving Casualties of Telecom was in fact the subject matter of the discussion between Mr Blount and Mr Lee some three or more weeks ago and, also, whether the internal Telecom document to which I referred was discussed by Mr Blount with Mr Lee.

I would be amazed if the latter were the case because in fact that document was only provided by a source, as it would seem, outraged by the fact that Telecom had purported to comply with a FOI request but had not made this document available. Of course, inspection of this document makes it clear that Mr Dawson's telephone line was being tapped without his consent. That is a crucial document that clearly should have been provided pursuant to the FOI request. To the extent it was not, Telecom has a very serious case to answer.

That is the matter that I want answered. I would not have thought that was in any shape or form the subject matter of the discussion between Mr Blount and Mr Lee. If it was, and if we are therefore being told that the matter is being investigated by the Federal Police, maybe we will have to accept that, although I disagree profoundly that that precludes the minister from making any public statement about the propriety or otherwise of Telecom's admitted actions.

I do not have any confidence, in view of the haste with which that answer was given, that I can assume that that mid-January discussion did have anything to do with the internal document. So I ask the ministers to reflect further upon my questions, to take them seriously, to give a considered answer and to face up to what I think is a very important proposition—that is, that it is simply not good enough to ask privately that matters be investigated when, if there are admissions of wrongdoing or if there are matters that the minister regards with concern, they ought to be brought to the attention of the public as quickly as possible. Those persons who are adversely affected ought to have those matters confirmed to them, instead of continuing to pretend that somehow nothing has gone wrong and then finding that, day by day, evidence is emerging to the contrary.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS BILL 1993
It gives me great pleasure to introduce in the Senate the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1993.
This is a historic occasion.
Introduction of these seven bills brings to fruition efforts stretching back over twenty five years to develop a truly national approach to the registration of agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
It was only in July 1991 that the Commonwealth, states and territories' governments agreed to establish a national registration scheme to replace the eight state and territory schemes.

Since then, there has been considerable progress in implementing the scheme. From 1 July 1992, the Commonwealth has taken over from the states and territories all the evaluation of agricultural and veterinary chemicals. In July 1993, honourable senators, we saw the establishment of the National Registration Authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
From my perspective, we have come a long way in a short time. But there is further to go.

These seven bills will provide the NRA with its full range of functions and powers and they represent the final stage in the development of the national registration scheme for agricultural and veterinary chemicals.

Consistent with the government's commitment to a more open and transparent process for the assessment and registration of agricultural and veterinary chemical products, the government released this and the other registration bills as exposure drafts for public comment. Also, briefing sessions were held with the main stakeholders, viz: the states and territories; the agricultural and veterinary chemical industry; the rural sector; and consumer, public interest and environmental groups.

In response to the invitation to comment on the exposure drafts, 33 submissions were received from a wide cross section of the community. A considerable number of the suggestions have been incorporated into these bills.

The registration bills are fully supported by the AGVET chemical industry, the National Farmers' Federation, the Commonwealth agencies involved in the scheme and the state and territory agricultural agencies.

The consumer, public interest and environmental groups will welcome those provisions of the bills which will ensure improved public participation, greater availability of information for the public, the public's right to seek an injunction and empower the NRA to hold public and private hearings.

I should emphasise, however, that the AGVET code is being introduced without the formal agreement of the states or the Northern Territory. I propose to seek the necessary agreement before the AGVET code is debated during the 1994 autumn sittings. In this regard, I wish to acknowledge the generous assistance provided by the states and territories in developing the scheme and the draft legislation.
I now wish to specifically address the provisions of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill.

The purpose of this bill is to make provision for the AGVET code to have effect in the Australian Capital Territory. The code contains provisions for the evaluation, registration and control of chemical products. Furthermore, the code is to be adopted by the legislatures of the states and the Northern Territory as a law of those jurisdictions.

This bill also provides that the whole legislative package will commence on a date agreed to with the states and Northern Territory. In view of the need for the states and Northern Territory to enact complementary state law, provision has been made for the act to commence 12 months after royal assent or earlier by proclamation.
The bill, through the "federalisation" mechanism applies the Commonwealth Acts Interpretation Act 1901 for the purpose of uniformly interpreting the AGVET codes as applied in each jurisdiction.
Also, the Commonwealth administrative law package will apply to the AGVET code in each jurisdiction.

In order to reduce the complexity of the bill, offences will continue to be offences against the laws of the states or territories, although the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions will be empowered to prosecute for offences.
This bill repeals the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988, which is replaced by this legislative package.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS CODE BILL 1993
It gives me great pleasure to introduce in the Senate the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Bill 1993.

This bill is to be enacted in the Australian Capital Territory. It has been drafted in complementary adoptive form so that the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code (AGVET Code), scheduled to the bill, can be adopted by each state and the Northern Territory. Through this mechanism, evaluation, registration and control of agricultural and veterinary chemical products, and related matters, will be administered uniformly across Australia by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (NRA).
The control measures apply up to the point of retail sale with the states and territories remaining responsible for control-of-use matters.
I now turn to the provisions of the bill.
The AGVET Code focuses on the registration of chemical products, approval of active constituents, and approval of labels.
The over-riding criteria to be addressed by the NRA are public health, occupational health and safety, the environment, product performance, and trade and commerce.
The public will be invited to comment in respect of each chemical product containing a new active constituent prior to determination of an application.

The NRA will also be able to reconsider an existing registered chemical product to ensure it continues to meet contemporary safety and performance standards. The public will be invited to nominate chemical products to be considered for inclusion in this formal and systemic review program.
In addition, the NRA will be able to review a chemical product at its own initiative. If appropriate, the NRA may suspend or cancel the registration of a registered chemical product.

Recognising the cost of additional scientific data when required to support continued chemical registration, compensation provisions have been introduced which will apply in certain circumstances. The intention is to recognise research and development costs associated with updating data packages when such data may also support other manufacturer's products. The provisions will apply to data specifically requested by the NRA and where that data does not have patent protection. A considerable number of safeguards have been built into the AGVET Code to prevent the commercial abuse of data while ensuring that both the provider of the call-up data and a secondary applicant are treated equitably.

The NRA will be able to control the possession of chemical products. It will be an offence to supply unregistered chemical products or to supply products in contravention of the conditions of their registration.

Where a chemical product has been supplied in contravention of the AGVET Code, then the NRA may issue recall notices requiring persons to stop supplying the product and to take action to deal with unsold stock as directed by the NRA.

A system has also been set up under which a person who wishes to do something in respect of a chemical product that would otherwise be an offence, may obtain a permit authorising the action to be done. For example, a person may want to conduct a trial or experiment in relation to an unregistered product in order to decide whether to make an application for approval or registration.

To ensure chemical products available to the public comply with the specifications determined by the NRA, this bill provides for the licensing of manufacturers of registered chemical products. The introduction of manufacturing principles is to be phased in over a period of time so as to allow the manufacturing industry time to adjust.

The NRA will have adequate enforcement powers in respect of the AGVET code. Authorised inspectors will monitor compliance with the AGVET code and, if contraventions are suspected to have occurred, to obtain search warrants. In various circumstances inspectors will be empowered, or may be given powers, to enter and search commercial premises and seize things. An inspector may also require the giving of information or the production of documents. The code also provides that any person may seek an injunction to enforce compliance with the code.

To facilitate the NRA being able to seek a wide spectrum of professional advice in respect of its evaluation of chemical products and active constituents, the NRA will be able to release confidential commercial information. However, I emphasise that precautions will be taken to ensure that trade secrets and certain other information subject to possible commercial exploitation are safeguarded. Each person in receipt of confidential commercial information will be bound by the confidentiality provisions of the AGVET code.

It is important to note that there are extensive provisions whereby an applicant can have a decision of the NRA reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT), including for example, refusing to grant registration of a chemical product. Before applying to the AAT for a review of decision, an applicant may, if they wish, request the NRA to reconsider the decision at no significant cost to the applicant. If the matter is not resolved, it can be referred to the AAT. These two appeal mechanisms will, I believe, provide a balance between the powers of the NRA and the concerns of applicants.
Transitional provisions have been provided which will ensure a smooth transition of existing arrangements to the new AGVET code.

This bill, I believe, provides for the efficient and timely registration of agricultural and veterinary chemical products. At the same time it will enhance safety standards and consumer confidence by involving the public in the evaluation process which will be accountable, open and transparent.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1993
It gives me great pleasure to introduce in the Senate the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1993.

This bill amends the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 and the Copyright Act 1968. The amendments are a consequence of the introduction of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Bill 1993, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Bill 1993, and the repealing of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act 1988.

This legislative package extends the functions of the National Registration Authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals (NRA) to include the registration and control of agricultural and veterinary chemical products. The new functions have been developed in consultation with the states and territories to ensure a consistent approach to the assessment and control of chemical products.
Furthermore, the NRA is to have regard to the government's policy in relation to the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

Also the NRA will be required to comply with the policies of Commonwealth, state and territory governments that are determined under an agreement to be entered into between those governments for the purpose of this proposed Act and the AGVET codes.

Other major amendments to the Administration Act concern the importation, manufacture and exportation of chemical products. It will be an offence to import a chemical product that is unregistered, not exempted, or for which a permit has not been obtained from the NRA.

Australia's international obligations in respect of agricultural and veterinary chemicals are also addressed. This will ensure that Australia can enforce its international obligations under prior informed consent arrangements.
The enforcement provisions are very similar to those contained in the AGVET code of which details were provided in the second reading speech.

The NRA will be able to hold public and private hearings to assist it in the exercise of its functions. The holding of hearings is a strong step towards the NRA's operations being open and transparent, and seen to be such.
The bill also makes some consequential amendments to the Copyright Act 1968 so that the reproduction of the writing on a label for a chemical product is not an infringement of any copyright.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICAL PRODUCTS (COLLECTION OF LEVY) BILL 1993
It gives me great pleasure to introduce in the Senate the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Products (Collection of Levy) Bill 1993.

Honourable senators will be aware that in deciding to participate in the national registration scheme, the government decided that the full cost of the scheme would be recovered from industry, phased in over a four year period. The National Registration Authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals will manage the cost recovery program associated with this bill.

The levy will be a significant component of the scheme's cost recovery program. Other funds will be collected through application fees and annual registration renewal fees. In 1994-95, 83 per cent of the scheme's costs will be recovered from the AGVET chemical industry and in 1995/96 the scheme will be fully cost recovered.
I wish to emphasise that the AGVET chemical industry has been extensively consulted on these cost recovery arrangements.
I now turn to the provisions of the bill.

This bill will provide the NRA with the mechanism by which a levy on agricultural and veterinary chemical products can be collected. The bill identifies how liability for payment of a levy charge will be determined and the amount of levy that will be imposed. Generally speaking liability for the levy will be based on the sale or disposal of chemical products in Australia. In addition the bill allows for the authority to make an assessment as to whether a levy payment is required and the amount of the levy (if any) that is due. It also makes provision for a review process for persons dissatisfied with a levy assessment.
I commend the bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
