SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY (HOME CHILD CARE AND PARTNER ALLOWANCES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill gives effect to a significant initiative announced prior to the

SPEECH.PARA: 1993 Federal Election.
A new Home Child Care Allowance is to be introduced from September 1994. The Department of Social Security will pay it each fortnight.

The Home Child Care Allowance reform consolidates the Government's provisions that assist families with children. It provides more direct recognition of the considerable time, energy and personal support devoted to children by parents, generally mothers, who decide to stay at home to raise their children. For the first time, this support will be provided direct to the parent caring for children, rather than to the other partner as a tax concession.
The Allowance will replace the Dependent Spouse Rebate currently available to couples with dependent children and be paid at a higher maximum rate of $60 a fortnight.

About 55,000 families whose tax liability was previously too low to get the full value of the Dependent Spouse Rebate available to couples with dependent children will receive greater assistance from the new Home Child Care Allowance.

The new Allowance will also be more responsive to families' needs than the Dependent Spouse Rebate. A parent leaving the workforce at any time during the year to, say, care for dependent children, will be able to claim the Allowance in that year, instead of waiting to re-establish their entitlement in the following year. This flexibility is expected to assist up to 120,000 families whose circumstances change within any year.

The new Home Child Care Allowance will not be means tested on family income. Dependent partners with children and incomes below $10.85 a fortnight will receive the full $60 a fortnight. Those with income of up to $250 a fortnight will receive part payment. Some 840,000 families in total are expected to receive it at any one time.

Home Child Care Allowance will be tax free and indexed annually. It will be paid until the end of the calendar year in which a dependent child, generally the youngest child, turns 18, or until the child ceases secondary schooling, whichever happens first. It will not be paid where the child is a prescribed student child except where the child is qualified to receive payments under the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme. A prescribed student child is a young person who has turned 16 and is qualified to receive payments under a prescribed educational scheme such as AUSTUDY or ABSTUDY. Families will have to meet Family Payment residency qualifications.

The Dependent Spouse Rebate for couples without dependent children and the Sole Parent Rebate will remain unchanged. Families that receive the new Allowance will not be eligible for these rebates. Legislation to prevent dual eligibility will be introduced later.

Current taxation arrangements provide for a beneficiary rebate to protect full-year allowees from income tax, but the rebate assumes that for couple allowees, the family receives the full value of the Dependent Spouse Rebate. Abolishing the Dependent Spouse Rebate for couples with children would have left full-year allowee couples with dependent children with a large income tax bill. Currently these couples receive one combined payment. This payment will now be split so that each member of a couple will receive their own payment, with the dependent partner receiving a new Partner Allowance paid directly to them. Each partner will also get a tax rebate so that they don't have to pay tax on their basic allowance. As a result, dependent partners of maximum rate Job Search, Newstart and Sickness Allowances and Special Benefit will generally not be eligible for Home Child Care Allowance as they will receive the maximum rate new Partner Allowance in their own right.

Both the Home Child Care Allowance and the Partner Allowance build on recent family assistance reforms that together will result in over $3 billion of assistance to families being directed to the primary care giver, usually the mother, each year.
The Government has a strong commitment to assist families. The initiatives contained in this bill reinforce that commitment and are timely in view of the forthcoming International Year of the Family.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
CRIMES (SEARCH WARRANTS AND POWERS OF ARREST) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to implement the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law to make much needed reforms to the law relating to search, arrest and related matters for the investigation of most Commonwealth offences.

SPEECH.PARA: These areas of the law have been the subject of careful examination by the Law Reform Commission in its report `Criminal Investigation' and more recently by the Review of the Commonwealth Criminal Law established by Mr Bowen as Attorney-General and chaired by the Right Honourable Sir Harry Gibbs GCMG, AC, KBE. The Bill closely follows the recommendations made by the Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law in its Fourth and Fifth Interim Reports.

The Review Committee made recommendations to modernise Commonwealth law to ensure that both technological advances are taken into account by these laws and the increased awareness of the need for Parliament to state clearly the balance considered appropriate between the community interests in effective law enforcement and the maintenance of individual rights and freedoms. To date laws in this area have been contained in numerous Commonwealth statutes, State and Territory laws applied by the Judiciary Act, police instructions or general orders and case law. This has lead to a considerable degree of uncertainty and inaccessibility of the law.

Indeed, recent public concerns about the Victorian Government's Crimes Amendment Bill highlight the need for this Parliament to make specific provision for laws relating to search, arrest and related matters in the investigation of Commonwealth offences. As the law currently stands, without this legislation, Commonwealth investigators are required to use State powers.

All these amendments will not initially supplant all other Commonwealth laws in this area as was envisaged by the Review Committee, those other laws are being carefully examined and brought into line with the provisions proposed in the Bill. It is intended to ensure that other officers, particularly those not subject to the training, discipline and accountability of members of a police force, have no greater powers than police. Until that review is completed, those laws which relate to the investigation of specific offences against Commonwealth law such as customs, quarantine and fisheries offences will continue to operate for police and inspectors appointed under those Acts.

The Bill provides for a comprehensive scheme for obtaining and executing search warrants, including telephone warrants, stopping and searching conveyances, arrest and related matters such as personal searches, taking and destroying fingerprints, holding identification parades and other identification procedures. It sets out the powers and obligations of police when carrying out any of these procedures and spells out the many safeguards to protect the rights of individuals.
I now mention some important features of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Bill precludes the issue by lay justices of warrants for search or arrest in relation to Commonwealth offences. Only magistrates and justices of the peace or other persons employed in a court who are authorised to issue search warrants and arrest warrants, as the case may be, will be able to issue such warrants. Further, the Bill recognises 3 different types of search to which a person can be subjected and lays down a clear criteria and procedures for their conduct. Practical difficulties which might otherwise flow from the removal of the power of lay justices to issue warrants are to be met by the introduction of telephone warrants. Easy access to magistrates or court employed justices of the peace is assured by the ability to use telephone, facsimile or other electronic means. The Bill creates a number of new offences in relation to applications for search warrants made by telephone and other electronic means. There is also a general offence, applicable to all warrants, of making a false statement in an application for a warrant.

The Bill prescribes in considerable detail the procedure which a police officer must follow to obtain a search warrant. The intended scope of the warrant must now be clear on its face. For example, if it is contemplated that a warrant obtained to search premises also authorises the search of persons at those premises, the warrant must clearly state this. Furthermore, to prevent the unnecessary execution of warrants on homes at night, the hours during which the warrant may be executed must be specified in the warrant.

If a police officer applying for a warrant suspects that, in executing the warrant, it will be necessary to use firearms the issuing officer must be told this and the reasons for this suspicion so that he or she can take this into account in deciding whether to issue the warrant. This is particularly directed to situations where, given the nature of the offence and the character of the suspects, it is more likely than not that violence will occur and it is anticipated that special weapons squads will be used. It is not, of course, intended to preclude the use of firearms where this is necessary in the circumstances as they develop when the warrant is being executed.
The Bill requires that a copy of the warrant be made available to the occupier of the premises or to the person to be searched.
The force used in the execution of the warrant cannot exceed that which is both necessary and reasonable.

Search warrants will authorise the seizing of evidence of the offence to which the warrant relates as well as evidence of any other indictable offence. A warrant to search premises may, at the discretion of the issuing officer, also authorise the search of people at, or near, the premises when the warrant is executed who are suspected of being in possession of evidence or dangerous items. Any person searched must be shown a copy of the warrant.

The Bill puts beyond doubt the right of police to be assisted by non-police experts. This will be particularly useful when the execution of the warrant involves operating computer equipment to locate evidence of an offence. The Bill permits the operation of equipment so that any incriminating evidence may be secured and retrieved but ensures that appropriate care is exercised to minimise damage to equipment. However, if damage is caused as a result of insufficient care in its operation, compensation may be payable to the owner of the equipment.

The Bill preserves the law relating to legal professional privilege. The current guidelines developed between the Australian Federal Police and the legal profession in relation to seizure of documents from solicitors' offices will continue to apply.

The Bill classifies personal searches as "ordinary", "frisk" and "strip" searches. A search warrant issued in relation to a person may only authorise a "frisk" or "ordinary" search. Procedures for any form of personal search, either under warrant or conducted after arrest, are strictly circumscribed to ensure both the effectiveness of the search and maintenance of the privacy and dignity of the person searched. Strip searches may only be conducted after arrest if authorised by a police officer of the rank of superintendent or higher.

Generally, searches must be conducted by a person of the same sex as the person being searched. Strip searches cannot be conducted in the presence of any person of the opposite sex except where a medical practitioner of the same sex is not available or where the other person is a parent, guardian or personal representative and the person being searched does not object.

The existing power of police to stop and search vehicles in emergency situations contained in sections 10A and 10B of the Crimes Act, which were also based on the recommendations of the Review Committee, will be re-enacted.

The Bill introduces into Commonwealth criminal law a general offence of failure of a person to give his or her name or address to a police officer who has reason to believe that the person is able to provide information about a Commonwealth offence. Such an offence exists in many specific enactments but there has been no general provision such as exists in other jurisdictions.

The Bill gives effect to the Review Committee in recommendations to repeal sections 8 and 8A and to replace them with more detailed and precise provisions about when arrest without warrant is permissible.
The power of arrest without warrant by members of the public (citizens arrest) is limited by the Bill to suspected indictable offences in specified circumstances.

Although the power to apply for, and issue, warrants for the arrest of persons for Commonwealth offences continues to derive from State law under section 68 of the Judiciary Act, the Bill imposes a number of additional procedural requirements.

The Bill provides for a scheme for the taking of identification material, including finger, hand and footprints, voice recordings and handwriting samples from a person in lawful custody for an offence. A police officer of the rank of sergeant or higher may take identification material if the person gives written consent or if that police officer believes on reasonable grounds that the taking of material is necessary to establish the identity of the person, identify the person as having committed the offence or to provide evidence of an offence. There are limits on the retention of the material.

The Bill expressly preserves other laws, including State and Territory laws applied to Commonwealth offences, by virtue of section 68 of the Judiciary Act, relating to the taking of forensic samples. Although this is a very necessary bridging provision to ensure that Commonwealth investigators have continuing access to law enforcement powers, the Commonwealth has reservations about some aspects of the Victorian Crimes Amendment Bill. Accordingly, I foreshadow that I will be bringing before the Parliament later this year a proposal relating to the taking of forensic samples as they relate to the investigation of Commonwealth offences.
It regulates the holding of identification parades and the carrying out of other identification procedures.

The Bill provides for the return of items seized (whether under warrant or not). It also provides that where a police officer needs to enter premises under a warrant or for the purpose of arresting a person he or she is required to announce his or her authority to enter the premises. This is designed to minimise damage to property or injury which can occur where the occupants are surprised. This safeguard was bolstered by Government Amendments in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is designed to make public the powers of police and the rights of individuals in the important areas of police investigation with which it deals. In the past many of the areas covered have been dealt with in police instructions or general orders which are not generally available to the public. This is incompatible with modern concepts of open administration and access to justice. I believe the Bill makes a significant advance in clarifying the powers of police and the rights of individuals in these important areas of police investigation.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate
VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill reflects the Government's continuing concern for the welfare of veterans and their dependants. In Building On Strength, the Government announced as part of its advancement towards a fairer Australia that it would improve the position of low income retirees by easing the pensions assets test and by introducing a seniors health card.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government fulfilled the first part of this commitment by introducing legislation to ease the pensions assets test from 20 September 1993. This bill meets the second part of that commitment by introducing a seniors health card from 1 July 1994. This card will give certain low income non-service pensioners access to concessional pharmaceutical benefits and hearing aid concessions as well as entitling them to dental and optometry services. It is estimated that this proposal will assist a total of 10,000 veterans and dependants.
This bill improves the assessment of child related payments for service pensioners. The main features include:
the ability to redirect child related payments to the partner;
adjusting the pension payment in shared care cases so that the child related payments are also shared;
backdating child related payments to the first payday after the date of birth in those cases where notification is received within thirteen weeks of the birth; and
ensuring, where pensioners have children and are receiving maintenance income, the maintenance income only affects the child related payments.
These changes result in a more equitable method for assessing child related payments and flow from the family payments structure under the Social Security Act.

The bill also contains three measures concerning the assessment of managed investments. As all these changes are beneficial to service pensioners with managed investments, it is proposed that they commence from 1 April 1993.
The first clarifies the legislation by ensuring that all losses can be offset against profits from other managed investments.

The second ensures that where an investment has been held for less than twelve months and only an interim rate of return has been declared, that rate will be maintained as the annual rate of return. Applying the current provisions, the interim rate of return is extrapolated for twelve months. This can result in a higher rate of return being maintained in the service pension assessment than the actual rate of return over a twelve month period.

The third measure addresses certain friendly society investments. In the current economic climate a number of friendly societies have changed status. Under the Act, a change in the status of a friendly society would affect an investment made with that company. The investment would be considered as "realised" and any profit that has accrued would be maintained in a person's service pension assessment for twelve months. This measure would safeguard these investments by providing that where the conditions of the investment remain substantially the same, the current assessment rules will apply. Profits from the investment will not be assessed until it is "realised" by some other method.

This bill provides consistency in the arrangements for offsetting compensation payments against disability pension for the same incapacity or death for which compensation is paid. At present, these provisions apply only to disability pensions paid under Part IV of the Act in respect of defence or certain peacekeeping service. The amendment ensures that the offsetting arrangements will also apply to disability pension paid under Part II in respect of war or operational service. These provisions will apply only to payments of compensation made after the date of Royal Assent.

The bill also clarifies the operation of the tax file number provisions where a person fails to comply with a request for a tax file number. In such instances, the Veterans' Entitlements Act currently directs that the person's pension or allowance is not to be paid.

The amendments set out the effect of failing to comply with a request for a tax file number and introduce a generous reconsideration period. It is proposed to give the person three months from the date the pension was last paid to comply with the request for a tax file number and still receive full restitution of the cancelled payment. This would allow the person time to consider the consequences of failing to provide the tax file number. If a person complies with the request after the expiration of the three month period, the pension or allowance will be restored from the payday after compliance.
This three month period is in addition to the 28 days that the Secretary already allows the person to comply with the request before action is taken to stop the pension payment.
This amendment puts beyond doubt the intention of the legislation.

Another initiative simplifies the current arrangements for withdrawing an application to determine qualifying service or a claim for service pension. It allows for a person to orally withdraw a claim and to reactivate the claim, within 28 days of its withdrawal, without penalty to the original claim. This initiative is consistent with the aim of assisting pensioners in their dealings with the Department by encouraging oral communications.
Finally, this bill will make a number of minor changes in the area of service pension assessment including a series of technical and consequential amendments.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: OFFSHORE MINERALS BILL 1993
This bill, and the associated bills, replace the existing Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 and amend its associated acts.
Mr President, at this stage the Senate should note that whenever the word states is mentioned in the rest of this speech it also including the Northern Territory.

The existing act, which is a consequence of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement, provides the legal framework for the exploration for, and the production of, minerals other than petroleum on Australia's continental shelf that is under Commonwealth jurisdiction.

The Offshore Constitutional Settlement divided the jurisdiction over the mineral resources of Australia's continental shelf between the Commonwealth and the states. The states have jurisdiction within coastal waters adjacent to them, while the Commonwealth has jurisdiction from the outer limit of coastal waters to the edge of the continental shelf.

Under the Offshore Constitutional Settlement it was agreed that there would be a common offshore mining code that would apply to the whole of Australia's continental shelf beyond the territorial sea baseline proclaimed by the Commonwealth in 1983. This common offshore mining code will be governed by a package of complementary Commonwealth and state offshore minerals legislation.

The revision of the act is a result of the states' dissatisfaction with it and an unwillingness by some states to enact complementary offshore minerals legislation so long as it remained in its present form. They considered that the existing act was not suited to the needs of the offshore minerals industry.

The Commonwealth agreed to a comprehensive joint review of the act with the states. Following this review a large number of amendments was agreed to by the Australian and New Zealand Minerals Energy Council ministers in 1990.

The government also took the opportunity to have the legislation re-written in the "plain English" style, recently adopted by the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel, to improve its readability so that it could be understood more easily by those who will use it. The end result is that this bill contains many new features in relation to its overall organisation as well as in relation to individual provisions.

In the preparation of the bill the Commonwealth closely consulted the states and in doing so drew on their extensive experience in minerals administration which has been greatly appreciated. The states at the same time confirmed their commitment to a common offshore minerals code.
The bill, when enacted, will provide a model for state complementary offshore minerals legislation which will provide a common mining code to operate in areas under their respective jurisdictions.
While the bill extensively modifies the mining code it preserves those principles in the present act which flow from the offshore constitutional settlement arrangements. Those principles are:
all offshore mineral activity in the Commonwealth area adjacent to a particular state is governed by a joint authority, consisting of the relevant Commonwealth minister and state minister;

the joint authorities are responsible for major decisions relating to titles, such as grants, refusals and the like, and in the event of a disagreement, the views of the Commonwealth minister prevail;
the day-to-day administration of the Commonwealth legislation is carried out by the relevant state and they are the primary point of contact between industry and governments.

As this bill deals with rights associated with minerals exploration and exploitation it ensures that this legislation is consistent with the government's policy in relation to native title. The provisions for the granting of licences are non-discriminatory and administrative procedures, which are already in place, will ensure that aboriginal interests are consulted when considering applications for any of the licences which may be issued under this act. Operators will be required to respect Aboriginal rights and interests.

The bill also retains the provision that offshore mineral royalties will be shared 60/40 in favour of the states. This sharing arrangement will apply to all minerals recovered under the authority of the common offshore minerals code.

The states retain, and will continue to retain, all fees received from title holders and applicants for titles. This is a recompense to the states for the expenses incurred in administering the Commonwealth legislation.
The bill is divided into chapters.

Chapter 1 covers the usual formalities, the constitutional and political background, the basic principles and concepts flowing from the Offshore Constitutional Settlement, including the establishment of the joint authorities.

Chapter 2 is the actual mining code itself, which is written to reflect modern mining administration practice, and because of this, it differs substantially from the cumbersome mining code in the existing act.

The bill clarifies how applications for exploration licences are to be received and treated. As a general rule the applications will be allocated on a "first come, first considered" basis. The exception to this rule will be where applications for substantially the same area are received at the same time. On such occasions ballots will be used to determine the priority as to which application is to be considered first.

The bill streamlines the existing provisions so that the manner in which an exploration licence is granted is simplified. It also alters the term of exploration licence renewals whereby the initial period will be for 4 years plus an option of 3 renewals of 2 years each. The maximum total term of a licence remains unchanged at 10 years.
The only major change in the provisions concerning the mining licence is the reduction in the maximum number of blocks from 50 to 20 for each licence.
The bill provides for the introduction of a new title called a retention licence. This will be an intermediate form of tenure, between an exploration licence and a mining licence.

Its primary purpose will be to allow the holder of an exploration licence to retain for a strictly limited time, title to an area on which a significant deposit has been delineated and evaluated, but which is not a commercially viable proposition in the short term although there is a reasonable prospect for development in longer term.
Under this title the holder will not be able just to sit on the area but will be required to undertake further work according to the conditions laid down by the joint authority.

The bill introduces a provision which will require applicants for a title to lodge securities as a condition of title. These securities, which may be varied up or down during the life of a title, will be used to ensure compliance with the legislation, regulations and conditions of the title.

The securities may also be used to pay for rectification of any environmental damage as a result of operations, rehabilitation of the title area's environment and the settlement of any outstanding financial obligations.

The bill provides for the creation of an instrument to be called a "special purpose consent" to undertake scientific investigations and reconnaissance surveys, and to collect small quantities of minerals. The consent will be a non-exclusive authority and it will not give any right or priority should an exploration licence or any other title be applied for later.
The remaining chapters of the bill provide for the normal requirements associated with mining administration.

Chapter 3 of the bill provides for the keeping of a register and the details that are to be entered into it and so on. It also provides for dealings in licences and authorities and the details of the procedures that are to be followed.
Chapter 4 provides the administrative details of the offshore minerals code such as information management, monitoring and enforcement, review of decisions, administrative procedures and finance.
Chapter 5 provides for the application of state laws to the offshore area under Commonwealth jurisdiction and miscellaneous matters.
The provisions in the five associated bills deal with money matters and are contained in separate bills.

The Offshore Minerals (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1993 amends the associated fees acts. The Offshore Minerals (Retention Licence Fees) Bill 1993 deals with fees payable for retention licences. The Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Royalty) Amendment Bill 1993 amends the royalty act. The Offshore Minerals (Exploration Licence User Charge) Bill 1993 and the Offshore Minerals (Retention Licence User Charge) Bill 1993 impose user charges on exploration and retention licences as announced in the 1993/94 budget.

Discussions are still under way with the states for the establishment of a common offshore minerals royalty system and further amendments to the associated royalty act will be forthcoming at a later date.

These bills provide a modern legal and administrative framework for the offshore mining industry which will help it grow as the years go by. They are a further demonstration of the government's micro-economic reform program to ensure, in co-operation with the states, that the barriers to the development of Australian offshore minerals industry are minimised so that it can compete in the tough world trading environment.

It is intended that once this legislation package is enacted, the states will introduce complementary offshore minerals legislation to apply within their jurisdiction. This will give effect to the agreement for a common offshore minerals code to apply right round Australia.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
OFFSHORE MINERALS (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1993
Mr President, this bill is part of the package of offshore minerals bills. It repeals the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 and amends the associated money acts, that is:
the Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Exploration Permit Fees) Act 1981,
the Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Production Licence Fees) Act 1981,
the Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Registration Fees) Act 1981 and
the Minerals (Submerged Lands)(Works Authority Fees) Act 1981.
The bill amends the names of the acts and makes other changes to the terminology to fit in with the language of the Offshore Minerals Bill 1993. The new names of the acts will be:
the Offshore Minerals (Exploration Licence Fees) Act 1981,
the Offshore Minerals (Mining Licence Fees) Act 1981,
the Offshore Minerals (Registration Fees) Act 1981 and
the Offshore Minerals (Works Authority Fees) Act 1981.

The main substantive amendment to the acts is the provision for the levels of fees to be set by regulations. This will enable more convenient amendment of the levels of fees when such an amendment is required to reflect the costs of administration of the legislation.
The levels of fees have not been amended since 1981 and it is intended that new fees to be set by regulations would double the existing amounts.

The intended annual fees are $20 per block for exploration licences, $200 per block for mining licences and $20 per hectare for works licences. The registration fee for the transfer or other dealing of an interest in a licence will not be raised and will remain at 1.5% of the value of the dealing.

The bill sets a ceiling on the amounts that may be prescribed by regulations. The ceiling is not intended to reflect any intended rises in fees but merely provides an upper limit for fees well into the future.
The bill also provides that multiple holders of licences are jointly and severally liable for the payment of any fees.

It should be noted that, in accordance with the Offshore Constitutional Settlement, administration of the offshore minerals legislation is carried out by the states on behalf of the Commonwealth. The fees collected are paid to the states in recompense for their administrative effort.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
OFFSHORE MINERALS (RETENTION LICENCE FEES) BILL 1993
Mr President, this bill is part of the package of offshore minerals bills.

The Offshore Minerals Bill 1993 introduces a new form of title called a retention licence which would allow a company to retain a proved mineral deposit without working it, if it could demonstrate a good reason for delaying production.

It is intended that the fee will be set for the present at $200 per block. The maximum area of a licence being 20 blocks this could mean a maximum annual fee of $4,000.
I commend the bill to the honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and report by 30 August 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: All matters pertaining to the marketing of the Disability Reform Package (DRP) and in particular:

TAB.TAB: (a)the circumstances surrounding the letting of the contracts to market the DRP;
(b)the management of the contracts to market the DRP by the Management Committee and its sub-committees;
(c)the nature and the extent of debts owed to creditors that relate directly or indirectly to contracts to market the DRP;
(d)the extent to which the Commonwealth may have been mischarged by companies contracted to market the DRP;
(e)the reasons why advice from two of three departments on the Management Committee to terminate a contract to market the DRP was not heeded;

(f)the circumstances surrounding the letting of a further contract in April 1993 to a company that was contracted to market the DRP, although it must have been suspected that the company was in financial difficulty;
(g)the doubts expressed during Senate Estimates about the objectivity of the liquidator appointed to a company that was contracted to market the DRP;
(h)the extent to which the strategy that was adopted to market the DRP effectively met its objectives; and
(i)the adequacy of current guidelines and practices for the letting and the management of contracts in the circumstances of the marketing of the DRP.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion concerns the marketing of the disability reform package, an issue I have taken an interest in since the contracts were originally let in mid-1991 for a project with a total value of about $7 million, based on a two-year strategy and to be completed in June 1993. The aim was to inform the community, people with disabilities, doctors and people working with those with disabilities about changes to the disability reform package. The main contractor for the marketing of the disability reform package was a company called Corporate Impacts which was contracted by the Commonwealth to receive $4.95 million.

PARA.TAB: Corporate Impacts went into provisional liquidation prior to the completion of the contract. As at the end of last year 130 creditors including people with disabilities and service providers had not been paid. Some of the creditors contend that Corporate Impacts was working under the umbrella of the Commonwealth and that the Commonwealth was liable for these debts. That assumption was made because sometimes the employees of the company worked out of Commonwealth offices and used a logo that was also used by departmental officers. Sixteen of the network facilitators employed by Corporate Impacts to market the disability reform package were also owed money. When we asked questions in estimates committees, Commonwealth officers contended that the Commonwealth may have been mischarged up to 13,000 head hours at an average of $45 per hour by Corporate Impacts as well as $220,000 by two designated officers to the contract and a significant number of other items, including an undisclosed number and value of deliverables, which at that time had not been obtained by the Commonwealth.

Upon asking questions at the estimates committee, I discovered that no checks of Corporate Impacts's financial capabilities had been undertaken prior to the letting of the contract. Within a year of the commencement of the contract, two of the three departments on the management committee contended that the contract should be terminated, but no effective action was taken.

Three departments were involved, and also the Office of Government Information and Advertising, with an officer from that department chairing the committee with three people from the different departments. That committee seemed to change as different representatives came from the different departments. There seemed to be a lot of problems in the way in which this project was managed because it went across three different departments.

Corporate Impacts was supposedly paid on a monthly basis, but by February 1993 it had received all except $62,000 of the $4.95 million for the total contract and the contract was not supposed to be completed until June 1993. So some explanations are required as to why all but $62,000 was paid out well in advance of when the contract was to end. Despite the ongoing concerns about the contract, Corporate Impacts received a further Commonwealth contract in April 1993—weeks before it applied for voluntary liquidation.

In the estimates committee a Commonwealth officer expressed concern about the objectivity of the liquidator. One former member of the management committee is taking legal action against the director of Corporate Impacts on the grounds of defamation. It was also claimed in the estimates committee that one of the Commonwealth appointed valuators was threatened with legal action by Corporate Impacts. That has apparently been resolved. Two separate evaluations have cast doubt on the effectiveness of the marketing project.

While the progress of this contract raises serious concerns, the letting and supervision of it has wider ramifications in exposing major deficiencies in the administration of the Commonwealth's procurement policy. There are questions about the adequacy of current mechanisms used to manage contracts that cross three Commonwealth departments, plus OGIA, and about the adequacy of current procurement guidelines that apply to marketing and advertising contracts as distinct from contracts for materials and goods.

I pursued this matter across estimates committees. One of the problems was that three departments were involved, so I had to ask questions of those three departments and of the Office of the Government Information and Advertising. That made it extremely difficult to ascertain all the relevant facts because sometimes I would find out one detail from one estimates committee by which time the other estimates committee had finished. It became obvious during the estimates process that that was not the most satisfactory means of obtaining all the information.

There are also a number of non-government witnesses who may wish to provide evidence to a Senate inquiry about this contract. Again, that avenue is not available through an estimates committee. In addition, a large number of people who may have been mentioned in the estimates committee deserve a right of reply. For all these reasons, I commend this motion to the Senate. I look forward to the support of my colleagues on this side of the house.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The referral of issues to the various Senate standing committees is not an easy decision, especially as a larger and larger workload is put onto the shoulders of members of these committees. The Australian Democrats discussed this issue at length, and went through a process of first asking what the issue was: was it an issue of merit? I will not go back over this and argue the merit of the issue. Senator Patterson has done that very well. In this case it is not just a question of the impact on the community—which is very interested in the marketing of the disability reform package—but also a question of the use of government moneys, and exactly how taxpayers' moneys have been spent and where they have gone.

PARA.TAB: Beyond the issue we have to look at what other avenues have been tried. As Senator Patterson has just said, the estimates committees have been used extensively. The new system with the estimates committees takes out of this chamber a lot of the work, and possible questioning of ministers. As well as looking at three departments we have to look at what other avenues can be tried.

Another issue the Democrats had to look at is the actual pressure on these committees. The Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs is perhaps under more pressure than almost any other committee. On balance, having gone through this process, our answer was, `Yes, this is an issue of merit. It has been pursued through other avenues. Despite the workload on the committee, it is an issue that we believe cannot be let lapse'. Therefore we will be supporting Senator Patterson's motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade and Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been around this track a few times. I have to say it is hard to understand how people can justify the priority which they are proposing to give to this matter. I still fail to understand, after the several opportunities we have had to examine and discuss this matter, what in the main is intended to be the target of this inquiry. One part is obvious and, subject to the point Senator Lees makes about the priority which the committee wants to give to this as against other matters, it is a perfectly understandable matter to inquire into. The question is: has the outcome of this program justified the expenditure in it? I understand that. That is something we should look into with regard to a whole range of our activities.

PARA.TAB: If the members of the committee—or a majority—think that is a matter they should look at, I will not quibble, even though I think other things are more important. It is a matter for the people who wish to conduct that inquiry rather than others. But there is a fascination with the process by which the people from Corporate Impacts were selected, and with the message that that might send about, firstly, whether the process itself is proper—and on this occasion whether it was properly conducted—and, secondly, the continually lingering innuendo that someone did something improper in making this choice.

As with many other decisions when they are examined, it probably does show up—and it has shown up—ways in which some parts of the process of inclusion on the short list might be improved. But there has been nothing to suggest anybody involved has acted in a way that is in the slightest improper. That would seem to be the only thing that would justify the commitment to an inquiry, unless there was a reluctance to provide information. But a vast amount of information was provided to Senator Patterson last year. It covered virtually everything in this notice of motion. This led to lengthy questioning on a previous occasion, and nothing was disclosed that warranted further investigation.

There are not any further facts to be elicited. We have been providing everything that has been asked for. The full circumstances are already on the public record. They have been dealt with several times by the estimates committee. I keep hearing all sorts of rumours that somebody was supposed to have made this decision on behalf of a special friend of the government—or something. I do not have the slightest idea what the connection is supposed to be or with whom it is supposed to exist, other than that it may be that one of the people involved stood for preselection for the Labor Party 20 years ago. There is a longer sentence for standing for preselection than there is for murder.

I know that one of the people apparently involved, one of the principals of the company, stood for Labor Party preselection only because I was told so in the Senate. I had never heard that before. In all the years I was in the Labor Party I did not know that the person had ever even been in the Labor Party. So if this is a great conspiracy, it is a pretty stale old affair; it is 20 years old.

Alternatively, people may think there is cause for concern about whether the Commonwealth has been properly billed, or perhaps overcharged, for the work that was done; about the bankruptcy of the company concerned; and other such matters. The Australian Government Solicitor is currently investigating a number of the matters to ascertain whether there are grounds for legal action, not within the government, but in terms of our relationship with other parties.

It is therefore going to be extremely difficult to have a useful inquiry while those other inquiries are under way.It is not that we are refusing to cooperate. We are quite relaxed about the matter. It is just that there is going to be a combination of tedious repetition and matters that are extremely difficult to pursue because of concurrent legal action that may be under way.

It is also proposed that the committee should look at an evaluation of the marketing of the DRP campaign. No-one can object to that. That is an expenditure of the taxpayers' money. The parliament is entitled to look at how effectively the money has been spent. But there has been a formal process of evaluation in the normal course, as all such campaigns of any magnitude are evaluated, and it is not finished. I am advised that the overall evaluation, taking into account several separate research evaluations of different aspects of the campaign, cannot be available for about two months. So the committee is going to charge in with half the information and try to make a decision.

Such research as has been completed has already been made available to Senator Patterson. We have advised her that further research on the evaluations will be provided when we get it. So this is the world's least covering up cover-up. Every bit of information about this research that I am aware of has been provided. She wants more information—I am not aware of anything that has been asked for that has not been provided—but we do not need a major committee inquiry to try to provide it.

If the committee decides to go ahead with an inquiry, well and good. I suspect that at the end of the day it will say—on the basis of the bit of research that I have seen, and there is more to do and it may not come to this conclusion—that we need to tighten up the administration of how organisations get on the short list, but overall this was a cost-effective exercise for the Commonwealth and the taxpayers. I know Senator Patterson will not say that because she has made up her mind before it has started.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—That is another reason why this inquiry is such a waste of time. I suppose making up her mind does not take very long.
—Ask how many general practitioners know about it.

—The research information may confirm Senator Patterson's views. If it does not, I will be interested in her apology in the Senate that she has been wrong on all these occasions. But I will not hold my breath.
—If you apologised every time you were wrong you would not have any time for anything else.
—If you apologised every time you were wrong you would not be a shadow minister.
—Senator Ian Macdonald is the exact opposite of Midas. Everything he touches turns to lead. He should just stay quiet for a while.
—Surely you could have used a better word than `lead'.

—`Lead' was the most polite word I could use in the Senate. I can count and I understand the Senate will resolve to have this inquiry. We will cooperate with it and provide the information as we have been providing it to the estimates committee and to Senator Patterson when she asks.

PARA.TAB: I have two concerns. The first is that there seems to be a fascination—not just in the Senate, but particularly in the Senate—that in some way inquiries are costless and that we can just go on having inquiries and there is no downside. It may be appropriate to drop some other inquiry off the list—I do not know the committee's full brief—but if it chooses to give this inquiry priority it is the committee's decision. Every time we add an inquiry it takes more public servants' time, it costs more money and it diverts resources. It is called opportunity costs. Each time we do this there is something else on behalf of the taxpayers we cannot do.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't need an economics 101 lecture.
—Yes, those opposite do. They should not need an economics 101 lecture but they do because it is quite evident—
—She couldn't get it from you.

—The last thing I want to do is pursue any more of Senator Ian Macdonald's tedious tangents. It is necessary to make clear that this is just not a costless exercise. There is a never ending repetition of inquiries. Those opposite are entitled to scour wherever they like to try to get up facts but they should not then seek to advocate that in some way they are about lean and efficient government because this is about diverting the government's resources from the primary tasks that the taxpayers provide their money for us to do. Taxpayers do not provide their money to pursue little exercises and fantasies that people have in their minds that somehow or other there might be a conspiracy in there somewhere if only we can keep looking. I do not suppose I can ever say that nobody in some far distant corner of the government has not conspired about something, but I know of nothing.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that this is the world's most fruitless potential search. But if the committee is determined to conduct this inquiry, we will not resist it. I resent having to divert the resources of the public servants, who are seeking to do a job on behalf of the taxpayer, to pursue these fruitless fantasies that keep coming before the Senate. This is just one more. If we have the inquiry, so be it; we will cooperate. I think all that will flow from it is tedium but it will be expensive tedium.

I think the Senate needs to give more attention, as do the taxpayers, to the fact that we are continuing to use money and resources, that could be used for worthwhile purposes, pursuing forlorn hopes, lost causes and flights of fancy. I think we should be a little more disciplined and rigorous. I understand the motion will be passed. I heard Senator Lees's comments and I know Senator Patterson's views, so we will not be dividing on this issue. I think it is a shameful waste of the resources of the Senate and the taxpayers and I think it will be proved to be so. But if that is the case, so be it.

DEBATE.TITLE: WET TROPICS OF QUEENSLAND WORLD HERITAGE AREA CONSERVATION BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: To which Senator Coulter moved the following amendment:

"but the Senate resolves to place on record its firm opposition to any commercial infrastructure development which impacts adversely on the world heritage values of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned last night I was highlighting the hypocrisy of the Australian Democrats and the Greens—particularly the Democrats—in their approach to environmental and Aboriginal issues. They distributed what they call serious amendments, a series of papers, and they did so without warning to me. They had not given me any notice nor had they given the shadow environment minister, Mrs Gallus, any notice of these proposed amendments.

PARA.TAB: If they had any desire whatsoever to have these amendments treated seriously and passed, they would have notified the major party in this chamber, one which represents more than 50 per cent of the Australian public, about their proposals. Yet they chose not to, instead deciding to play cheap little political tricks in a vain attempt to out-Green each other—that is, the Greens and the Democrats—and to clamour for the support amongst that ever decreasing number of followers of the very left in the spectrum of Australian politics.

The North Shore by-election, fortunately, has shown that the time of the Independents and the minor parties is finished—and what a good thing for Australia that will be. For the record, I note that immediately I had finished speaking on the second reading I noticed that the amendments had been left on my table. Immediately I finished speaking I had a look at those amendments and I walked across to see the duty minister who, at that time, was Senator Ray.

Senator Ray indicated to me that whilst he was not personally aware of what the bill was all about he was aware that these amendments had been received and he was able to tell me immediately and by consultation with his advisers that the government had considered these amendments and that they were intending to support some of the Democrat amendments and none of the Greens'. He also told me that Senator Richardson, who was aware of these things, would be coming down to the chamber to handle the matters through this parliament. I say to the Greens and the Democrats: `Do not compound your hypocrisy by lying about the issue of those particular amendments'.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—That particular expression should not be used again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will not use it again. If they had given these amendments to the government in sufficient time for the government to have considered the amendments and formulated a response, they could have given them to the Liberal and National parties in time to consider them. Had they done so, they may have saved themselves some embarrassment and they may have got some assistance from us in the amendments.

PARA.TAB: We will not be supporting the second reading amendment. The wording is too vague to mean anything sensible and the general thrust of the amendment is already clearly stated in the bill. No commercial developments have been allowed which impact adversely in the eyes of those who have the power to stop any such commercial activities. Obviously, there is no development, past or current, under consideration that falls into the category of causing adverse impact which the amendment seeks to deal with. If there was adverse impact in the current proposal or in any past proposal there is plenty of authority and power for existing agencies to prevent that. They have not done that so obviously it has not occurred. It is unlikely to occur because the power is already there and it does not need to be spelt out in this particular second reading amendment.

The skyrail project has been mentioned in the debate and it obviously has no adverse impact, as I mentioned, otherwise it would not have been approved by the Wet Tropics Management Authority, by the National Parks and Wildlife Service, by the local authorities or by the other agencies which have some interest in this matter. The skyrail project will be a great boost for tourism in Far North Queensland and will also allow ordinary Australians to experience at first hand the beauty and significance of the wet tropics in a manner which will not cause any damage to the rainforest or in any other way adversely impact on the area.

For the benefit of honourable senators, I will explain what the skyrail project is all about because, from the fairly benighted references made by other speakers, they may well be excused for thinking that the skyrail project will involve clearing and felling huge tracts of forests. The skyrail will run from Smithfield to Kuranda with two stops, one in the national park and the other next to the Barron Falls. Both are in the World Heritage areas.

The skyrail will consist of six-passenger gondola cabins. It is made of 37 steel towers, 25 of which are in the World Heritage areas. These towers are being installed by helicopter, each into an area of 10 metres by 10 metres. They are up to 40 metres high and are higher than the trees so as to provide a canopy experience for those using the skyrail. The idea of the gondolas and the skyrail project is to allow people to travel over the rainforest rather than through it. The whole development involves a total clearing of less than half a hectare. The CSIRO has stated that the skyrail cableway will allow people to experience the rainforest with less impact than any other means, including walking through the forest.

For five or six years the skyrail people went through the process of obtaining approvals and getting the right sort of environmental slant on these things. Eventually, in December of 1993, they lodged a $1 million cash security bond with the Queensland government to guarantee compliance with the development agreement and the environmental conditions.

Senators and all parliamentarians would oppose any development which did damage to rainforests or any other environmentally sensitive areas. This second reading amendment is, accordingly, unnecessary. The purpose of the bill which we are passing is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to facilitate the implementation of Australia's international duty for the protection, conservation, presentation, rehabilitation and transmission to future generations of the Wet Tropics of Queensland . . .

that is, to protect and preserve those rainforests. We do not need this amendment to amend what the bill is all about. How can we do the sorts of things that the bill requires if we allow in commercial activities which adversely impact upon the World Heritage values? This second reading amendment is motherhood stuff which has nothing to do with the legislation. It is all about the Democrats and the Greens trying to carve out a niche in the minds of the radical greenies and those to the far left of the political spectrum.

PARA.TAB: I understand that those in the Labor Party are agreeing with this amendment because, even though they know it is completely unnecessary, they have an eye to the second preferences. Of course, that is where Senator Richardson comes in, the past master at getting the second preferences from the greenies and winning votes on that. I think even Senator Richardson realises that all that sort of stuff is a thing of the past. Why they are bothering to support this amendment, which is what the bill is all about, is simply beyond me.

The stupidity of the Labor approach is that, by agreeing with the second reading amendment, they are conceding that the bill is not sufficient to do what it purports to do. It is really a vote of no confidence in the Wet Tropics Management Authority and, more importantly, it is a vote of no confidence in Mrs Kelly. I can well understand why they would have a vote of no confidence in Mrs Kelly, but it is a vote of no confidence in relation to this matter. Those in the Labor Party are saying, `We don't trust Mrs Kelly to keep out developments that impact adversely'. We know Mrs Kelly has the power to do that but for some reason members of the Labor Party, by agreeing with this amendment, are saying, `We know Mrs Kelly has the power to stop it, but we don't trust her to stop it and, therefore, we are going to agree to this amendment'.

Regarding the foreshadowed amendments, we can only agree with the government on the Democrats' proposed clause 6A and 5A(2) that it is not appropriate for this parliament to tell the Queensland parliament what it should do. In any case, if we look at the Democrats' proposed clause 6A, we see that it requires the minister to use her best endeavours to have the Queensland government `ensure that any advisory committee established by the Authority under the Queensland Act includes among its members Aboriginal representatives'. That is what the Democrats want us to do.

If the Democrats look at the agreement between the Queensland government and the Australian government that we are dealing with in this bill, they will see that there is provision for a community consultative committee and that the people included on it will come from various areas, including the Aboriginal community. We are confirming what is already there in the agreement, yet the Democrats want to move another amendment to say it again. It shows how stupid they are and the lack of attention they give to these details.There is a scientific advisory committee with some requirements and, again, Aborigines could be appointed to that if they have a sufficient amount of scientific knowledge.

With regard to foreshadowed amendment 5A(1), we support the concept that the Wet Tropics Management Authority should have on its board `one or more Aboriginal representatives who have appropriate knowledge of, and experience in, the protection of cultural or natural heritage'. The Liberal and National parties agree with that. We also think there should be an environmentalist on it and someone from local government and someone from the promotional areas around Cairns. We also believe that there should be women and men on it, but we are not going to change the act to make sure that local government is represented or that environmentalists are represented. All of those people can be put on the board if they have sufficient standing, and that is the same with Aboriginal people.

Surely we should be getting the very best persons for the job regardless of their race if they have the standing and the ability. I know Aboriginal people have that. I know they are skilled. They can be appointed to that board today, and they should be appointed today. Why Mrs Kelly refuses to do so, I do not know. Maybe she will have to answer for that. It is up to the government to do that today if it wants to. It does not need this bill to appoint Aboriginal persons to that board. I cannot understand why this amendment is necessary. My time has run out. I want to say quite a bit more about the appointment of people to that board, but I will do that in the Committee of the Whole debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I request that my amendment relating to the preamble be put to the chamber before the amendment of the Democrats. SPEECH.PARA: (1)Page 1, after the Title, insert the following Preamble:
"This preamble sets out considerations taken into account by the Parliament in Australia is enacting the law that follows.

"The General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization adopted the World Heritage Convention for the purpose of assuring the protection of the world's cultural and natural heritage of outstanding universal value.
"Australia is a party to the Convention.
"The Wet Tropics Area has been listed in the World Heritage List kept under the Convention as forming part of the world's natural heritage of outstanding universal value.
"Australia has an obligation under the Convention to ensure the protection, conservation, presentation, rehabilitation, and transmission to future generations, of the natural heritage of the Area.

"It is the intention of the Parliament that the Area should be established and maintained as a world heritage area of the highest standard and that the Commonwealth will take all steps necessary to ensure that this is the case.
"The Commonwealth and the State have, under the Agreement, agreed to broad structural and funding arrangements in relation to the management of the Area.
"It is, therefore, the intention of the Parliament to make provision, by this Act, to ensure that effective, active measures are taken to meet Australia's obligations under the Convention.
"Aboriginal people have occupied, used and enjoyed land in the area since time immemorial and have managed and shaped the natural environment.

"Natural heritage is part of the cultural landscape of Rainforest Aborigines and is important spiritually, socially, historically and culturally to aboriginal people particularly concerned with the land.

"It is, therefore, the intention of the Parliament to recognise the role of aboriginal people particularly concerned with the land in the Area and give aboriginal people a role to play in its management.".

This amendment, which I foreshadowed in my speech during the second reading debate, relates to presenting the context in which this bill is to operate. It serves as a preamble and, as has already been mentioned, it contains the sections that will later be referred to in the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that it might be appropriate at this stage that I make some general comments on all of the amendments. It may save time to do so now rather than when we go through them individually. I might indicate what the Liberal and National parties' attitude is towards Senator Chamarette's amendment and the amendments proposed by the Greens. PARA.TAB: We will be opposing the Democrat amendments to insert in the bill clauses 5A(2) and 6A, which seek to allow this parliament to tell the Queensland government what it should do. Clause 6A seeks to get Aboriginal representation on advisory committees but this is already in the agreement which this bill is facilitating. This provision relating to Aboriginal people is in that agreement.

It is simply another example of the Democrats trying to make these political points without any real consideration of the issues involved.

In my speech in the second reading debate I was indicating that we supported the concept of an Aboriginal representative on the authority board, which the Democrats propose through the inclusion of proposed section 5A. We support the general thrust of the idea that there should be an Aboriginal person who has the appropriate knowledge of and experience in the protection of cultural and natural heritage to the Wet Tropics Management Authority board.

We also support—I repeat—the suggestion that there should be a local government representative on that authority board, because the local governments are inextricably involved in the management of these areas and the access to and from them. As well, of course, local authorities are locally elected, democratic organisations which are in the best position to adequately represent the views, concerns and aspirations of the people of the particular area. So it is essential that there be a local government representative on that authority board.

As well, we believe it is essential that there be someone on that authority board who would mirror the interests of the tourist operators and developers, who have a very great interaction with the wet tropics management area. It is only by having those developers and operators that we can, sensitively and in a controlled and environmentally friendly way, get these areas to a stage where they can be accessible to ordinary Australians—not just those who can wander through them as long as they like and do not have to worry about the normal constraints that ordinary Australian families have. We want to make provision—and the tourist operators do this—for ordinary Australians to have the opportunity to get in and have a look at those rainforests. So we think there should be a representative of those sorts of people on the board.

We also think that there should be a representative of the environmentalists on that authority board. That is essential. In fact, the government has agreed with that by appointing Dr Aila Keto, a well-known environmentalist, to that authority board. Nothing in the legislation says that she has to be appointed but the government has said that it is sensible, and we agree that it is sensible to have an environmentalist on the board, and so it has appointed her. The situation is similar with local government. There is nothing in the legislation now that says that a local government person has to be appointed, but we have such an appointee in Councillor Tom Pyne, the Chairman of the Mulgrave Shire Council. He is there because he should be there, and because there should be a representative of local government. But that is not made mandatory in the legislation; it is up to the government to appoint these people, and it has.

Similarly, it is important, as I mentioned, that there be a promotional person on the board, and the government has agreed with that and appointed someone. But that is not written into the legislation; it is not mandatory. It is for the government to decide and it has decided. And the situation is similar with regard to an Aboriginal person. We believe that such a person should be appointed to the board. It is up to the government to do it. The government now has all the power that it needs to appoint someone. Mrs Kelly can do it if she wants to; and, if she does not want to, perhaps Senator Richardson could tell us why that is the case.

There is every power there now for Mrs Kelly to appoint an Aboriginal person if that person is the best person for that particular authority—and surely we should be getting the very best persons for the board of this very important authority, regardless of racial origin. People should not be appointed as Aborigines. They should be appointed as Aboriginal persons who have some real connection with the area. If, as I suspect, there are Aboriginal persons who have the appropriate knowledge of and experience in the protection of cultural and natural heritage and who can work in the broader thrust of preservation, maintenance and enhancement of the wet tropics rainforest, and if such a person would make a contribution at least equal to that of any other person who might be appointed, then that person should be appointed. As I have said, Mrs Kelly has the power to do that now. There is no need for special legislation; the power is already there.

Such a person should be appointed for his or her suitability, not for his or her racial origin. I know that there are many Aboriginal persons who would do a marvellous job and who should be considered, but that could and should happen under existing legislation. As I mentioned, this is another example of the shallowness of the Democrats' legislation and the political games that they play—attempting to win votes but holding no real concern about or interest in the substantive issues.

The amendments proposed by the Democrats come from the leader of the party. It amazes me that the leader of the party could have got it so wrong. She has moved an amendment proposing something already provided for in the bill in order to try to score some cheap political points for a party desperately trying to maintain a constituency on the very left of the political spectrum, and it is doing that in the face of a concerted push for that left wing vote from the Western Australian Greens.

With regard to the two proposed preambles—one proposed by the Greens and one proposed by the Democrats—I point out to the Senate that clause 3 of the bill, which we have all agreed should be passed, sets out the object of the bill. It clearly sets out the purpose of the legislation. Clause 3 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Act is to give effect to the agreement . . . and to facilitate the implementation of Australia's international duty for the protection, conservation, presentation, rehabilitation and transmission to future generations of the Wet Tropics . . . Area.

That is a clear setting out of the purpose of the bill. The Democrats' preamble talks solely about Aboriginals and their attachment—nothing about the objects of the bill as set out in clause 3. I would ask Senator Richardson and his advisers to consider this.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot might like to get some legal advice on the nature and effect of preambles in legislation. She might find out that the preamble is a statement of intention as an aid to interpretation, but that it is secondary to the specific clauses of the bill. It is in clause 3 that the objects of the bill are given, and they tell us what the legislation is all about. The preamble proposed by the Democrats is contrary to the specific clauses of the bill in that it is contrary to the specific reference made in clause 3. It is, again, fairly typical of the grandstanding of the Democrats—making some political point no matter how irrelevant it is to the serious business before the parliament. Perhaps it is a preamble which the Democrats might want to move to any legislation that comes before this parliament, because it is as relevant to any other legislation as it is to this particular bill.

The preamble proposed in the Greens' amendment is more relevant, particularly in its first eight paragraphs. They would very clearly assist the bill if that preamble were to be part of the legislation, because that preamble does set out what the bill is for; it is directly in line with the object of the bill set out in clause 3 and would be very relevant. But, unfortunately, the final three paragraphs also deal with Aboriginal issues and they are not at all relevant to the bill, particularly as the Greens' amendments do not in any way attempt to mention, involve or include Aborigines, leaving that part of the preamble standing completely alone and without relevance to the bill, particularly with respect to the specific provisions of clause 3.

Accordingly, while not necessarily disagreeing with the sentiments of the preamble where they are raised in the appropriate place and in the appropriate legislation, we will not be supporting these preambles and these amendments to this particular piece of legislation because they are not relevant. They simply give a further example, if one is needed, of the action of the Democrats and the Greens in making political points without taking any account of the real issues before us in the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I want to indicate that we are not supporting the Greens' amendments which comprise the additional clauses that run before the Australian Democrat clauses on the preamble. PARA.TAB: As Senator Ian Macdonald said earlier, in large part the preambles are contrary to the aims and objectives of the act, and are almost ultra vires. The matter of serious concern is that they really achieve little except to make a political statement. I agree with Senator Ian MacDonald when he says they are a cheap political statement. During the debates on the budget and the Native Title Bill, to name two, we saw an almost unedifying display of the two parties on the cross benches fighting each other for media attention.
