However, from my point of view it is almost unedifying to see these senators chasing each other for the media spotlight when they debate these things. It is therefore not surprising to see that we have two pious preambles competing for the support of the Senate today.

As Senator Ian Macdonald said, the coalition parties will not be supporting these amendments because we see them for what they are. They do not assist the process of managing the wet tropics area in the way the initial legislation set out to do.

This is a matter I covered when the Senate debated world heritage issues on previous occasions, but I want to spend a very short amount of time on the whole process of world heritage listing and on trying to take the politics out of it. Senator Coulter was present in this place when I made my earlier remarks on this subject. World heritage listing is a most controversial thing in Australia. As is well-known to senators, there is this continuing conflict involving the genuine hopes and aspirations of those who care for the environment and would like to see the environment protected and managed in a way that protects what are genuinely world heritage areas for the benefit of future generations, for the value of the amenity to those people who can enjoy it here and now, and for the value of the biodiversity, the flora and fauna and all the other aspects of heritage and environmental protection. These are very genuine hopes and aspirations, and they are good policy objectives when trying to maintain those values.

The competing objective is economic development involving the hopes, aspirations and control of the local infrastructure and environment by local people. Every time we talk of world heritage—and this particularly applied during the 1980s which Senator Richardson knows more about than most people—we get this political conflict between the locals, the state government and the federal government. When world heritage listing is proposed we get this massive conflict with the right wing rednecks going around saying, `Watch out: Canberra will take control of your land', and, `Watch out for the nasty politicians and bureaucrats from Canberra'. The people from Canberra—generally the Australian Labor Party over the past 10 years—say, `Don't worry, we will look after you. We will give you money; we will give you resources on the ground and we really won't try to take over land management'.

Today we are here debating one of the last pieces of legislative action to try to resolve those political difficulties in relation to the wet tropics. The danger here is that with people like the Democrats and the Greens competing for this common part of the constituency that they seek to attract by putting what I call these pious preambles into the legislation, one then further politicises the whole process of world heritage. It will then be made so much harder for Australia to list successfully world heritage properties in the future.

This subject is political enough as it is. I will not repeat them all, but if we seek to have references to Aboriginal links to the land and the inclusion of Aboriginal delegates on committees and various other bodies set up under the act, then we will give people on the ground even more reason to kick political cans and be anti-world heritage in principle.

I genuinely believe that in principle world heritage can be a good thing, but it is all to do with how the process is achieved. We know what happens if these things are achieved working from the ground up rather than by working from the top down. This was the case with the wet tropics, with Shark Bay, as Senator Richardson knows, with the Nullarbor and with Lake Eyre as the result of a ministerial announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —We haven't mentioned the Nullarbor yet.

—I am talking about the process and about how the announcement is made. All of a sudden the pastoralists, tourist operators and everyone else in the area get scared about the prospect of world heritage listing, and immediately the people in Canberra and the politicians involved who are actually proposing the world heritage listing are on the back foot straight away. If one has to go to a hostile meeting on Lake Eyre, a hostile meeting on the Nullarbor or a hostile meeting on Shark Bay, one is fighting backwards because the government has decided, for whatever noble reasons, to draw a line around an area on the map of Australia and call it `world heritage'.

PARA.TAB: I am suggesting to the Senate that those over there on the cross benches—that is, the Greens and the Democrats who, of course, if there is a double dissolution, will be fighting for the No. 12 position in Senate elections in all states of Australia—are trying, at this late stage, to seek further political mileage from this fighting amongst green constituencies and amongst the natural supporters of the Greens and the Democrats to see who can make the most pious preamble to the world heritage legislation. In the long term they could do serious damage to the whole process of world heritage listing.

Senator Macdonald has referred to the more specific point about mandating that we must have an Aboriginal person on the board. I am sure it is genuinely meant by both the Greens and the Democrats. When it comes to appointing Aboriginal people and mandating that we must have an Aboriginal person appointed to the tribunal, we made the point during the native title debate that it is a form of tokenism and paternalism that will not help Aboriginal people.

Senator Macdonald made the point very well that a whole range of people should be involved in the process of managing this world heritage area and that we need to protect the interests of local people. There is no doubt that some Aboriginals within the wet tropics area have important links with that area going back a long time. I do not know about those links—I have not studied the Aboriginal heritage in that area, so excuse me for not seeking to be an expert on them—but I am sure that Aboriginals have links which possibly go back to before white settlement. I do not know whether that is the case; that is a definitive statement. But there is no doubt that many other groups of Australians, as Senator Macdonald has said, need to have a say in the management of this area.

If this body is doing the right job, it will consult with all of those people. To mandate that we must have an Aboriginal person—in other words, make a racist mandate—would of course be making a big mistake in our eyes. It should be made quite clear that the coalition's view is that we should make sure that the board and the people involved in managing the wet tropics world heritage area are very cognisant of the hopes and aspirations of the Aboriginal people in this area. Senator Richardson has given us an assurance that the government has already had a number of consultations with the Aboriginal people in relation to the extraction of wood for their own purposes.

There is no doubt that the coalition fully supports that consultation. But, again, for what I consider to be cheap political reasons, the Democrats are proposing to put into legislation a form of racial discrimination which will not only hurt the world heritage process but, indeed, hurt the process of reconciliation which we all talk so much about in this place. We do not seem to get anywhere because all we seem to do is talk about it and make these crass political forms of tokenism and paternalism which do not actually end up helping the Aboriginals on the ground anywhere around Australia.

I am afraid that these amendments are politically motivated. I think they are being moved as amendments for the wrong reasons. It is quite sad to see what I think is a hijacking of what is already a highly controversial area of public policy. I am very glad that the coalition parties will not be having a bar of what I think are quite pious and crass amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the situation to be now in relation to the Australian Democrats' amendments, the preamble is being supported by the government and the Greens; proposed clause 5A(1) is being supported by everybody in the chamber; proposed clause 5A(2) is being supported by the Greens and the Democrats but not the government and the opposition; and the third amendment, proposed clause 6A, is being supported by the government, the Democrats and the Greens, so I think it will be necessary to put the amendments separately. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Page 1, after the Title, insert the following Preamble:
"This preamble sets out considerations taken into account by the Parliament of Australia in enacting the law that follows.
"Aboriginal people have occupied, used, and enjoyed land in the Area since time immemorial.

"The Area is part of the cultural landscape of Rainforest Aboriginal peoples and is important spiritually, socially, historically and culturally to aboriginal people particularly concerned with the land.

"It is, therefore, the intention of the Parliament to recognise a role for Aboriginal peoples particularly concerned with land and waters in the Area, and give Aboriginal peoples a role to play in its management.".

It seems to me to be very rich indeed for the opposition—which, during the Mabo debate, obfuscated and filibustered day after day with its hidden agendas in relation to not properly recognising the legitimate land claims of Aboriginal people—to now come back over this piece of legislation and object to the writing into this legislation of several clauses which in fact recognise what Mabo is all about. I think the opposition's going back over that ground now seriously puts in question its motivation, and we must seriously question whether its motives are indeed not being racist or disguised as political pejorative against both the Democrats and the Greens.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that world heritage recognises, under the world heritage legislation, a number of characteristics in areas which mark those areas off as world heritage. One of those characteristics which mark them off as world heritage is cultural connections. This seems to have been ignored by both Senator Campbell and Senator Macdonald when they say that the recognition of Aboriginal occupation of this area has nothing whatsoever to do with the objects of the act and with the declaration of this particular area as world heritage. It has a great deal to do with this area. The cultural attitudes of Aboriginal people which recognise the need to protect areas, the idea of living with the land, of being part of the land and of being brother and sister to the animals and plants which one finds among many indigenous people lies very much at the core of what Mabo is about. It is about the change in Australian society and about what world heritage is about. So if the honourable senators fail to see that, that is their problem. They are failing to see something which clearly the government, the Greens and the Democrats have recognised.

The Democrats are proposing three amendments to this bill which are designed to ensure greater recognition of Aboriginal people's traditional association with the area that will be subject to the operation of the Wet Tropics Management Authority. Our amendments are designed to ensure that Aboriginal peoples who have an attachment to the land and waters under the protection of the authority can participate in the management of the area.

That is the essential point: they are designed to ensure that they will be there and will be participating. We have heard Senator Campbell and Senator Macdonald express their attitudes, when they said, `Yes, they may be. It is up to the minister. The minister can appoint them'. Heaven help us if the opposition were to form government and opposition ministers were in there if they have the sorts of attitudes that we have heard today in relation to Aboriginal people. I do not think any Aboriginal people or any of their attitudes will be represented whatsoever. I think the notion that one writes this into legislation, that one attempts as far as one can to ensure that these cultural attitudes are represented by having Aboriginal people with the necessary qualifications represented in there, is absolutely essential. So the first amendment we put forward proposes that there be this preamble acknowledging the connection of indigenous people to this area. As Senator Richardson has pointed out, some indigenous people have long-lasting connections with the area and their cultural tradition is an essential part of the world heritage qualities and should be recognised as such.

It is to be regretted that the substantive legislation passed by the Queensland government covering the administration of the wet tropics area does not include a preamble. Our amendment goes some way to addressing this deficiency. Here, one needs to reflect on the history of the development of this legislation in relation to management: that, prior to Mabo, an agreement was entered into between the Commonwealth government and the state government; that, prior to Mabo, the Queensland government passed its legislation; but now, post-Mabo, the federal government is passing its legislation and clearly needs to recognise the deficiency—that is what these amendments attempt to do—which potentially lies in there and to fill that necessary gap. Things have moved on since 1990, thank God. Things have moved on since 1993—thank God—with respect to our recognition of the legitimate land claims of Aboriginal people.

The second and third amendments that we have put forward expand on this and make it the responsibility of the federal minister to ensure, upon consultation with his or her state counterparts and the Aboriginal groups concerned, adequate indigenous representation on the board of the authority and its committees. These amendments are specifically designed to encourage indigenous participation—not to just leave it open so that it may occur at the largess of the minister but that that be clearly identified.

I accept Senator Macdonald's point in relation to the legal strength of objects which are written as parts of legislation and preambles. But, as he said himself, the preamble is in fact a part to which law courts can look for further explanation and exposition of the purposes and the intent of the legislation. Therefore, it is quite appropriate that that be in there.

I am aware that a review of Aboriginal involvement in the authority is under way, and it is to be hoped that a memorandum of understanding will be drafted which makes a clear acknowledgment of the heritage and traditional association of indigenous peoples with the area and provides for their active participation in management. This recognises the fact that there is a time line associated with this process which has now run over about 3 1/2 years.

I urge those involved in the review to include in the memorandum an acknowledgment of native title claims. Such claims should be taken into account when management plans are being drawn up. I acknowledged in my speech during the debate on second reading that there has been quite serious mismanagement in relation to world heritage areas and management plans. If we are to have proper understanding and acceptance of world heritage by people with regard to, say, the Nullarbor and Lake Eyre, the government needs to do a lot more to ensure that management plans are put in place early. I think Mrs Gallus is suggesting in a possible amendment that some sort of preliminary management plan would alert people to what governments had in mind. This would be an excellent idea. I have no problem with that at all.

I note that in the Law Reform Commission's amendments to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as proposed in the report on the recognition of Aboriginal customs and laws, it was suggested that there be indigenous representation on the board and, further, that management plans be subject to consultation and negotiation with Aboriginal peoples. Our amendments go a substantial way towards addressing this. It is desirable that more direct legislative imperatives be put in place to ensure that the interests of Aboriginal peoples are considered.

It is disappointing that we could not wait until after the review of Aboriginal participation has taken place before dealing with this legislation; it may have been better to put the whole thing on ice for a bit longer. However, we considered that and rejected it as a possibility.

There may be some who will argue that it is not appropriate to move this type of amendment ahead of the review. However, it is our view that these amendments cover those exigencies, and the review may then come back with further suggestions for change. Our amendments ensure that simple legislative safeguards consistent with Commonwealth legislative and constitutional obligations to indigenous people—and these have changed since the Queensland legislation and since the Commonwealth-state agreements—are built into this bill. That is the basis of our strong support for these amendments. I formally urge on the Senate our first amendment which relates to the preamble.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly to the amendment to the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area Conservation Bill 1993 moved by Senator Coulter, and I will also give indications of our response to the other amendments moved by the Democrats. I draw attention to the fact that there is another Green amendment to be moved at the end.

PARA.TAB: When the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) was talking about the amendment to the preamble that has just been lost, he said that it was redundant or worse. If it is correct that it is stating the obvious and it is unnecessary to put the context in which this bill is being presented, well and good—as long as it is clearly understood that it is for the protection and preservation of the world's cultural and natural heritage that is present in the wet tropics of Queensland. The Greens felt that it was appropriate to have that initial opening. We also felt that the provision referring to the role of Aboriginal people with regard to their participation in any management of the world heritage area was appropriate. Therefore, it would be very remiss of us not to support the Democrat's motion. Whilst leaving out what the minister has said about obvious and well-placed confidence in the legislation, we will be prepared to support the provision that refers to Aboriginal people.

In responding to Senator Campbell's concern, the Greens do not feel that it is discriminatory to recognise the role of indigenous people in the care of significant environmental areas with which they have strong spiritual attachment. A lot of adjectives have been thrown around the chamber. It might be of interest to my colleagues to note that often I do not respond to any of these words. The reason why I do not react strongly against them is that, as a psychologist, I am very aware of the principle that whenever accusations are made they often reflect the accuser more accurately than the person who is being accused. I do not feel that there is any need to respond to the comments that were made earlier in that regard.

The Greens and the Democrats have presented slightly different amendments. These have come from requests in the community from slightly different perspectives. In particular, Aboriginal groups have requested the inclusion of a special clause in the preamble. The Democrats are providing such a clause, and we are happy to support it. We believe that it gives recognition and encouragement to Aboriginal participation in the management process. There is agreement rather than competition between the Greens and the Democrats on this count. We will be supporting all of the amendments moved by the Democrats. We would urge the government to reconsider its reluctance to support all of them. I appreciate Senator Ian Macdonald's comments in which he supported in part the underlying meaning of the amendments, if not gaining the opposition's support for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have come into the chamber in order to answer what I heard Senator Coulter say when I was listening to the broadcast in my office. He revisited the situation where anyone who says anything against any sort of Aboriginal motion or motive coming from the Greens, the Democrats, the government or whatever is a racist. That is exactly how he put it and exactly how I heard it. He then carried on about the line the opposition took in the Mabo debate.

PARA.TAB: As far as I am concerned, the Mabo legislation brought forward by this federal government was rotten to the core. We opposed every single clause of it, and we will continue to do so at any time when it may come back into the chamber for amendment or whatever. I make no excuse for that.

Senator Coulter said that Aboriginals, by definition of their ethnic group, have to be represented. If he wants to put expertise onto such organisations, committees, boards or whatever it may be, it should be done by merit, as Senator Ian Macdonald has already pointed out. Senator Ian Macdonald has already said that it could be done positively by this legislation. We have to pick the people who are suited, the people who are willing, and the people who have the expertise. If we go away from that basis, then what other stupid sorts of situations will we get in other legislation? Perhaps in sport we could legislate that so many Aborigines go into the Australian test side, so many Aborigines go into the AFL teams, and so many Italians go into the AFL teams.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a ridiculous analogy.

—It is not ridiculous. It can be legislated. What about the timber-cutters who worked in those forests and who were put out of work? Why do we not have some of those represented on the board? Perhaps they have expertise in that sort of situation. Why do we not legislate to put those people on those boards? Those are the people who have lost most. Some of them have never worked again. Senator Richardson knows that is the situation, so why does he not give them representation? While Senator Coulter—and anyone else—is prepared to stand up in this chamber and brand us as racist, I will come in and answer them every time.

—The coalition will not be supporting Democrat amendment no. 1. I again very briefly put on the record our reason for not supporting it. We have no objection to the sentiments contained in the preamble provided they are expressed at the right time, in the right place and in the right legislation. Our objection is perhaps technical in that the preamble is simply a statement of intention as an aid in interpreting the act.

PARA.TAB: The act is about environment and conservation; it is not about social justice packages for Aborigines. It is not about Mabo; it is about the environment and conservation. The preamble proposed by the Democrats is simply poor legal drafting. I cannot imagine that the government and its advisers would concede that the statute book should be cluttered with preambles with poor legal drafting that have nothing whatsoever to do with the purpose of the bill. The purpose of the bill is clearly mentioned in clause 3, which sets out the objects of the act. The objects relate to conservation but not to Aboriginal issues. I am at a loss to understand why the government, except for political reasons, would be supporting this amendment. They are the reasons why we oppose the amendment. It is not because we do not necessarily agree with what is said, but on the grounds that it is not being said in the right place, at the right time or in the right legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government supports this amendment moved by the Democrats. I am disappointed to hear the remarks made by Senator Panizza. There is no way that one can compare the situation we have here with how many Aboriginals or Italians there should be in the Australian test team or whatever. I fail to see that that is a reasonable analogy. Senator Ian Macdonald referred to Mabo. Every now and again something occurs that makes me proud to be in the Labor party: the Mabo legislation of last December was one such moment.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that Senator Ian Macdonald, Senator Campbell and others would not be aware of the fact that we did refer to Aboriginal attachment to this land and to the cultural aspect when we made our nomination of the wet tropics in 1988 at the World Heritage Convention. Having made that reference in our nomination, I really do not think it is too much to refer here to the links that Aboriginal people have with this land. I mentioned one community, but there are many communities that have links that go back many thousands of years, and certainly long before we played cricket. Therefore, I do not think it is unreasonable to refer to them.

There has been a tendency in this area and a whole range of areas for the interests of Aboriginal people to be last in the queue and very often to fall off it. It is not a bad idea to keep this government, and indeed all future governments, honest on this subject. I nominated an Aboriginal person on the first consultative committee back in 1988—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were required to.
—No, I was not required to; I just did it.
—Yes, you were. It is in the agreement.

—There was a difficulty nominating an Aboriginal at the time. A lot of pressure was put on that Aboriginal person because other communities thought that as it was to be an advisory committee only, they should all be represented on it. In fact, the person concerned eventually withdrew because of that pressure. It is my understanding that, because we are now talking about the board of the authority, Aboriginal people will accept that they should have a representative and that no pressure will be put on whoever might be the representative to withdraw. I think this is a step forward, not a step back. I do not regard this bill as some race to cultivate any particular constituency; rather I think it is just one more small example of us being just. It does not happen all the time. I wish it happened more often. I know the Aboriginal people in the area will welcome this decision.
—A bit of justice for Ravenshoe.

—Towns such as Ravenshoe have a much better chance of doing business as a result of the world heritage listing than they ever had through logging. The number of people employed had declined every year and was down to a couple of hundred when we nominated. We took a long-term view—and thank God we did. We would not have had a world heritage listing for the wet tropics if we had relied on those opposite because they would have logged the area until it did not exist.

—I thank Senator Richardson for those remarks which backed up what I said earlier; namely, that one of the three principal criteria on which areas are designated as world heritage areas is to do with culture. I pick up the point that Senator Panizza made—he has left the chamber again, but he may be listening to this in his room or watching on a monitor. If one were to select people on merit, and the criteria of merit was that they knew something about culture, who better to represent that particular view than the Aboriginal people who have lived in the area for thousands of years? So on merit they would be selected.
—So why mandate them on this?

—But Aboriginal people have been consistently left out of account, as the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, has just said. We are now attempting to redress that imbalance, that injustice, which has been perpetuated over the past couple of hundred of years.

PARA.TAB: I was also particularly pleased to hear what Senator Richardson said in relation to people who were logging. Senator Richardson said that it was not a question of whether those people would lose their jobs; it was simply a matter of when. If we continue to log the old growth forests without its being carried out properly in a sustainable manner, eventually all of those people will be out of jobs. So it was not a question of whether those people would lose their jobs, but when they would lose them.

The dedication of the world heritage area may well have brought some of that hardship forward, but the fault does not lie at the feet of the conservationists who are attempting to protect that area. The fault lies at the feet of successive administrations and the forestry industry which, over many years, failed to establish proper plantation forestry which would have ensured that those jobs would continue in perpetuity; in other words, a sustainable timber industry was not established.

While one must feel very sorry for people who were put in that position at the time, one must make the point that the fault does not lie at the feet of the conservationists. It lies at the feet of the forestry commissions and the state administrations which had not established those forestry plantations. As Senator Macdonald acknowledged yesterday, tropical rainforest plantation timbers are now, for the first time in the past couple of years, successfully being put in place. Hopefully, in future years a viable and long-term sustainable industry will be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us cut away some of the hypocrisy from the Australian Labor Party. If those opposite want an Aboriginal appointed to that position, why have they not appointed one so far? They have had every opportunity to do so but they have not. Yet, as always, they go on with this hypocrisy. They pontificate about it now when they think the eyes of the world are upon them. Mrs Kelly has had the opportunity to take that step for the past three years. Why has she not done so?
—I want to respond to a couple of points. I was going to ask Senator Richardson whether or not Aboriginal interests were originally put in the nomination—I presume they would have been.
—I said that when I spoke.

—Senator Richardson said it before I asked the question. That reinforces the argument that this is redundant. Honourable senators in this chamber, including the minister, have admitted it is very nice to make another reinforcing statement which will remind future governments down the track that we need to think of Aboriginals first and not last. I am glad to see that the nomination included reference to the Aboriginal heritage in the area. But, again, if those opposite want to go into preambles because it makes them feel good, then they may as well mention in the preamble all the other tremendous world heritage features of the wet tropics.

PARA.TAB: One may as well mention the waterfalls, the rainforests, and all the flora and fauna. That is why I keep saying it is being done for crass political reasons. I stand by my statement that it is a pious preamble which has no effect whatsoever, anyway; but the point is worth making.

I would also respond to what Senator Coulter said in reference to future coalition governments when it comes to appointing Aboriginal people. It is always easy for the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens to look at the coalition's views on things like the Native Title Bill and this bill and say, `Aboriginals will never get anything if a coalition government is elected.' That is a cheap statement which personalises and lowers the tone of the debate. I make my comments from a very genuine point of view—I made comments during the Native Title Bill debate after a series of Labor Party politicians criticised the coalition in relation to Aboriginal affairs.

Both sides of politics—including the Democrats—have a lot to be ashamed of for the way they have treated Aboriginals and Aboriginal issues for years, going back 30 or 40 years. It is fair to say that the coalition government under Malcolm Fraser and ministers like Ian Viner and Fred Chaney tried very hard to make progress on Aboriginal issues. It is probably fair to say that a number of ministers under the Hawke and Keating Labor governments have tried very hard as well. Many people are genuinely committed to the cause of trying to advance Aboriginals. But I do not think that just because one belongs to the Labor Party, the Greens or the Democrats one has a mortgage on empathy for the plight of Aboriginals. It is a sad reflection on anyone who says, `Coalition members are all anti-Aboriginal and the Labor Party loves Aboriginals because it keeps moving these bits of national land rights legislation and other things and supports pious preambles to bits of legislation.' We will fight this fight.

I will defend our record every time a Labor Party or Democrat politician gets up and has a go at the coalition and tries to attack the credentials of the coalition parties, particularly the Liberal Party, in relation to Aboriginal affairs. I will put on the record our genuine concern for all Australians; that Aboriginals do have some very endemic problems that need to be addressed by a nation that can stand up and be proud of itself. There are health, housing and education problems—problems that need special attention. But those problems are not assisted by politicians trying to score cheap political points.

We had a genuine commitment during consideration of the Native Title Bill to our belief that the Mabo II High Court decision was not the best approach for a whole range of reasons, one being that that approach would actually be counterproductive in solving those other serious problems of Aboriginal people. We stand by that approach. We think the government has made a very serious mistake in the way that whole process was entered into.

Even though the politics of the situation in this chamber towards the end of last year certainly did not come out in the coalition's favour for a load of reasons, which those who have been in politics understand, I am quite sure that in the long run Senator Richardson will be proven wrong. I am glad that he is proud of what his government has achieved, because in public life it is good to feel that one is achieving something. I think the government has made a serious mistake with the approach taken with the Native Title Bill, which in the long run will prove to be an economic disaster for Australia and, even worse, a disaster for the Aboriginal people whom the government sought to assist with its approach.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 3, page 2, lines 3 and 4, omit "(a copy of which is set out in Schedule 1 to the Queensland Act)", substitute "(as amended from time to time)".
I believe that the amendment, which is of a technical nature, will increase flexibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seriously, you don't need to do it; it just does not matter.
—The Greens have moved this amendment and I accept that there may be different views.

—We do not support the amendment. It is not necessary. As a practical lawyer, I believe that it is a much better idea to have the schedule to the act in the act rather than omit it altogether. If Senator Chamarette wanted the best of both worlds, her amendment could say, `A copy of which is set out in schedule 1 to the Queensland act as amended from time to time' and include them all. But simply as a matter of practical drafting, it is better to include it in the act because it is all there. If the agreement referred to is in the act it will make things much easier. Basically, Senator Chamarette's amendment is not needed and, again, it is improper drafting.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Page 2, after clause 5, insert the following clause:

"5A.(1)The Minister must include among his or her nominees under section 5 one or more Aboriginal representatives who have appropriate knowledge of, and experience in, the protection of cultural and natural heritage.
I understand that the opposition will also be supporting this amendment. I will not detain the committee any further.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no way in the world that we would be supporting this, for the reasons I mentioned earlier in the committee stage debate. I do not know what Senator Coulter was doing then but I made it quite clear that we would not be supporting this for the very reason that, whilst we support the concept of having an Aborigine on the board, we also support the concept of having on the board an environmentalist, a local government person, a representative of the tourism operators and developers and an independent chairman. That part is legislated for. We also support the concept of having men and women on the board, as appropriate in this day and age. But we support the concept of having the best people on it. All of those people can be on the board—it is up to the government to nominate them. We are quite happy for them to be nominated.

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has two nominations. Currently they are Mr Geoff Donaghy from the Cairns promotion bureau and Ms Aila Keto, the well-known environmentalist. The State government has two nominees: councillor Tom Pyne from local government and another gentleman, whom I do not really know. His name is McDonald, so he must be good, but I do not know what category he fits into. In addition, there is an independent chairman, Professor Ken Wiltshire, appointed jointly by the Commonwealth and state government. That is provided for in the agreement. Of course, the executive director also sits on the board.

I understand that the government is going to get together with the Greens and pass this amendment. Where does that leave us? The bill says that the government has to appoint one Aboriginal person and that the other person has to be only generally qualified. The agreement between the two governments adopted in the legislation indicates the type of person that should be on the board of the Wet Tropics Management Authority. The bill gives a broad definition that the chairman and members shall be persons having qualifications relevant to, or special experience or interest in, a field related to the functions of the management authority.

That is why I challenged the Australian Labor Party earlier. An Aborigine with those qualifications could have been appointed three years ago. Senator Richardson does not need this amendment to appoint an Aborigine. But if he does include this amendment, there will be one Aborigine and one other person having qualifications relevant to or special experience or interest in a field related to the functions of the management authority. That other person could also be an Aborigine. So there may be two Aborigines on the board. Good luck if they both have the qualifications. But one Aborigine is there because he is an Aborigine. This amendment is contrary to the agreement. There is going to be a field day for the constitutional lawyers, but that is not for me to worry about.

The Commonwealth is going to have to get rid of either Dr Keto, the environmentalist, or Mr Geoff Donaghy. It will be interesting to see which one goes. I am going to be around Cairns when this happens. Someone with specific environmental learning and qualifications will be put off the board. I do not always agree with Dr Keto—I rarely do—but she is an acknowledged expert in the field. Mr Donaghy is the representative of the Cairns promotion bureau. He does a tremendous job in promoting Cairns, particularly in the ecotourism area. He is promoting an industry which in Cairns has meant millions and millions of dollars, and hundreds of thousands of jobs to far north Queensland and North Queensland generally. They have all been associated with ecotourism in the wet tropics.

So either Dr Keto or Mr Donaghy goes. That is a choice the government has to make. If it wanted to put an Aborigine on the board it did not have to wait for this legislation. The government could have done it yesterday or three years ago. So the legislation is irrelevant, useless and unnecessary. That is why we are not supporting it.

What does Senator Coulter want to achieve? It is a matter for the government to pick the people, but that could have been achieved under the legislation as it is. The legislation does not need this amendment, so we are not supporting it. I will look with interest at what the government does about the persons who will be the Commonwealth representatives on this board.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—Senator Coulter, by way of clarification, I take it that you have formally moved the amendment to insert clause 5A(1)?

TALK.START.PARA: —I move :

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Page 2, after clause 6, insert the following clause:
Aboriginal representation on advisory committees

"6A.The Minister must use his or her best endeavours, through consultation with the Authority, to ensure that any advisory committee established by the Authority under the Queensland Act includes among its members Aboriginal representatives who have appropriate knowledge of, and experience in, the protection of cultural and natural heritage.".

In this post-Mabo era we are really making sure every piece of legislation that comes along recognises Aborigines.

PARA.TAB: We have just adopted page five of the agreement which is a schedule to this legislation and concerns the wet tropics world heritage area management scheme. It becomes part of the legislation. It is an agreement between the Queensland and Commonwealth governments and has been ratified today by the Commonwealth parliament.

Page five of that agreement, which is incorporated in the legislation which was ratified, says in part, `there shall be a community consultative committee', the only consultative committee associated with the wet tropics. We need only one such committee. It is a good committee and involves lots of people including local government people, the scientific community, conservation people, industrial unions, and people with interests in education, recreation, tourism, mining, commerce, primary production and the Aboriginal community.

So this is already there in the legislation. I understand the Australian Democrats do not look at such things closely and do not really understand how they work, but I cannot understand Senator Richardson and the advisers. Obviously they did not think it was necessary. That is why they did not put it in their original bill—it is already there.

Can someone tell me, please, why this provision is in an agreement that has the force of law now because it is ratified in legislation; it is a schedule to it. It has gone through the Queensland parliament which has adopted it. The Queensland parliament said, `Yes, there will be an Aboriginal person on this community consultative committee'. The Commonwealth has adopted it today. It has said it agrees and every community consultative committee will have an Aboriginal person. Yet a new paragraph is being added to the bill saying exactly the same thing. I excuse the Democrats. They probably do not know better; but I cannot understand the government and its advisers, except if they are doing it for purely crass, political purposes. Would someone please tell me why?

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly. I have the Queensland bill here and I am well informed on the schedule, the relevant page of which I have in front of me. As Senator Ian Macdonald said, this bill includes 12 categories of members among a 13-member community consultative committee—the community consultative committee, which is set up under this schedule. This amendment is to ensure that any advisory committee established by the authority under the Queensland legislation includes among its members Aboriginal representatives. Clearly, this anticipates the possibility of setting up other advisory committees in addition to the community consultative committee, which is mentioned specifically in schedule 1.

PARA.TAB: It is a matter of drawing attention at the time to the fact that world heritage is set aside to look after areas of scenic significance, biological significance and cultural significance. The area of cultural significance is one which demands that a person with merit in this area, who clearly is most likely to be a person of Aboriginal background because that is the long-term cultural significance of that area, would be on any—and that is the word used in the amendment—advisory committee established under the authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —The agreement clearly provides for two advisory committees, which is all there is: the community consultative committee and the scientific advisory committee. Obviously, the scientific advisory committee needs people with special scientific skills—whether they be Aborigines, Jews or Callithumpians. If they have the right scientific knowledge they will be on that advisory committee. On the community consultative advisory committee, it is all there. It is ridiculous to repeat it in the legislation. That is the reason we will be opposing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Amendment Bill 1993 is not a controversial bill and the coalition will therefore be supporting its passage through the Senate this evening.

PARA.TAB: The bill proposes to transfer guardianship powers of certain non-citizen children from the federal Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the state and territory governments. It does this by excluding children who enter Australia for adoption from the definition of non-citizen child defined in the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946. Following the passage of this bill in the federal parliament, state and territory governments will be able to assume guardianship when they have been declared by gazettal by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs after he is satisfied with the state and territory legislation.

The coalition supports this bill because it puts into legislative context what is current practice; that is, the federal Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs usually immediately delegates his powers of guardianship of adoptive non-citizen children to the relevant state or territory welfare administrator. There have, however, been exceptions to this practice. The most notable was the baby Kajal case several years ago when the federal minister intervened in the state adoption process by exercising his guardianship powers. The failure to follow usual delegatory procedures in that case raised concerns from state governments about the way the federal government had interfered in adoption procedures which essentially come under state jurisdiction.

Following a review into the federal government's guardianship powers, an understanding was reached by Commonwealth and state governments in 1990. This bill is the legislation required of the federal government to implement the 1990 understanding. Complementary legislation will be required by the states and territories. Although there will be a need for ongoing discussions between state and federal governments about the details of the complementary state and territory legislation, these are not part of the object of this bill. I understand these will be negotiated between the various states and territories and the federal government on an individual basis.

It is sensible, given there is clear state responsibility for adoption matters, that guardianship powers of children in particular states for adoption purposes should be with the states. It is for that reason that we support this bill because it is endorsing the current practice that has been in place for quite some time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill 1993 amends the Olympic Insignia Protection Act 1987 to provide increased protection against unauthorised commercial exploitation of the Olympic insignia. This is a non-controversial bill and therefore the opposition supports its passage through the Senate this evening.

PARA.TAB: Clause 3 amends the definitions section of the act and several definitions are extended, bringing them under the protection of the bill: firstly, the Olympic motto expressed in English as `faster, higher, stronger'; and secondly, a registered torch and flame design. The protection period for a registered torch and flame design for a particular summer or winter Olympic Games will be the period starting when the design is registered or on 1 January that is at least three years but less than four years before the opening of those games—whichever is the later. The protection period ends on 30 December after the closing of those Olympic Games.

The bill proposes a definition of Olympic artistic work which includes a prescribed Olympic torch and flame design under proposed section 2A or an artistic work that incorporates either the Olympic symbol or a prescribed torch and flame design. Clause 4 inserts a proposed new section 2A, which allows for the prescription of a single artistic work of an Olympic torch and flame for a particular Olympic Games. Such a regulation may be made only where the committee is the owner of the copyright or the relevant work.It is particularly significant that this is to protect the Olympic insignias. The protection is designed to limit the unauthorised commercial exploitation of the insignia.

Clause 5 proposes the repeal and replacement of section 6 of the act, which deals with ownership of the Olympic symbol. The AOC, which looked into this, is taken to be the owner of the design of the symbol and any design registered under the act before the commencement of this bill. Clause 6 provides that, in relation to an infringement of the monopoly in a protected design, a design may be a fraudulent or obvious imitation of a registered torch or flame design even if it does not incorporate a prescribed Olympic torch and flame. The opposition certainly supports this bill in terms of trying to protect the Olympic insignia, because it is a significant insignia, against exploitation.

Clause 7 provides that remedies under the act are in addition to those provided by the Trade Practices Act, especially those relating to misrepresentations about sponsorship. A major concern all the way along the line has been that people can use the insignia and, by doing so, can give the impression that that organisation or company is a major sponsor of the Olympic Games when that is not the case at all.

Clause 10, which requires the registrar, on application from the committee, to reduce the protection period of a registered torch and flame design, is also desirable. Clauses 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 and 13 propose minor technical changes and consequential amendments relating to the proposed addition to the act of registered flame and torch designs. Clause 15 proposes to preserve existing rights conferred by the Trade Marks Act 1955 and the Designs Act 1906. Clause 16 replaces all references to `the federation' with `the committee'. With that brief summary of the purpose and the intent of this bill, I inform the Senate again that we will not be opposing this piece of legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to support the Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill 1993 and to make it very plain that the Australian Democrats welcome this piece of legislation. As has already been mentioned in this debate, the Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill increases protection against the unauthorised use of either the commercial insignia or the symbols. The bill also seeks to stop what has been described as ambush marketing in the lead-up to the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: There have already been reports of goods illegally using the Olympic insignia being sold within hours of Sydney being announced as the host city. The Australian Olympic Committee has suggested to the Democrats that it has been seeking this type of legislation for several years.

The AOC says that the world body, the International Olympic Committee, has requested the strongest possible protection for Olympic symbols, particularly the Olympic rings and the torch. The Olympic motto, `faster, higher, stronger', will also be protected under this legislation. As the Australian Olympic Committee also states, official sponsors need to be protected. Those sponsors who have authority to use the Olympic symbols should not be undermined by organisations which use these symbols without the proper authority. An example of this occurred after the Barcelona Olympic Games in 1992 when a rival of one of the Australian team's major sponsors was able to cash in on the success at the games of the Australian athletes because this type of legislation did not exist. Unfortunately for the AOC, this particular sponsor has now ended its association with the Australian team over this incident.

While welcoming the Olympic Insignia Protection Amendment Bill, the Australian Olympic Committee is concerned that it may not go far enough. The AOC has used the example of the United States to highlight its concerns. Olympic insignia protection rules are very strong in the United States and any individual or organisation wanting to use even the word Olympic must have the expressed approval of the United States Olympic Committee. The Australian Olympic Committee and the Sydney Olympics Organising Committee have publicly called for measures similar to those in the United States. It appears that the government believes any attempt to restrict a word such as Olympic could be the subject of a legal challenge.

On a personal note, it is a little disappointing too that the legislation does not include any product labelling. This could have been a prime opportunity to ensure that any Olympic products carrying a `made in Australia' tag should truly represent goods that are fully Australian. However, the Olympic Committee assures me that a lot has been done in this area.

When the New South Wales government presented its legislation for the formation of the Sydney Olympics Organising Committee, it included a reference that the committee should ensure that Australian made goods were used wherever possible. The difficulty is that it will be very difficult in many instances to find goods that are truly fully Australian in both their content and manufacturing.

To conclude, it is clear that, despite some of the reservations, the overwhelming feeling is that this legislation should be passed. As I mentioned earlier, the Australian Olympic Committee has been seeking protection such as this legislation for many years. It is on that basis that the Democrats will be supporting this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution. I think the points that they have made do not really need to be trawled over again. But it is very timely that this piece of legislation is introduced. It is a matter of some concern, given the cost of trying to put on an Olympic Games, that people might want to take the money but not make a contribution.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I am concerned that the Australian Olympics and the international Olympics are assisted in all ways in making sure that maximum benefit accrues to Australian athletes and participants. I thank honourable senators for their contribution to this piece of legislation. I think it is timely and very worth while.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 16 December 1993, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1993. Once again, this is a non-controversial piece of legislation and the opposition will be supporting its passage. The purpose of the bill is to make necessary amendments to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act to ensure that all competitors tested by ASDA under complementary state and territory legislation have access to the same appeals provision as those tested directly under the ASDA act.

PARA.TAB: These amendments will enable the states and territories to confer jurisdiction for review of decisions by ASDA on the Commonwealth Administration Appeals Tribunal or the Federal Court, even though athletes are being tested by ASDA under state or territory legislation. These amendments will also allow the name of a competitor tested under state legislation who has returned a positive test result or who has failed, without reasonable cause, to comply with a request by the agency to provide a sample and whose appeals have not been upheld, to be entered on the register of notifiable events established under the ASDA act.

The amendments also include provision for the removal from the register of notifiable events the names of competitors who were tested under state legislation, which is consistent with those provisions applying to competitors tested directly under the ASDA act. While a number of state and territory governments have draft bills prepared, they cannot proceed until these amendments are completed. The opposition has one concern, I suppose, and that is that the states do not have comparable penalties. It is something that should probably be considered by the states. We will not be opposing the passage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats also welcome the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill. As we move towards the Olympic Games in Sydney in the year 2000, it is vital that Australia continues to play a leading role in the fight against drugs in sport. For this reason, the Democrats will be supporting this bill. To borrow a paragraph in the Australian Sports Drug Agency 1994 operational plan:

SPEECH.PARA: Sport is about participation, performance, competition, and achievement. Above all, it's about building character and improving the health and well-being of the nation. Drugs to enhance physical performance undermine the essential values of all that sport is about.

With the eyes of the sporting world focusing on Australia over the next seven years, we must ensure that action is taken to try to stop the use of performance enhancing drugs. The Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill will assist the national approach to drug testing by providing athletes who have been tested under state or territory anti-drug legislation with access to the same channels of appeal as athletes tested under the Commonwealth act. In other words, all athletes will be treated equally in this respect. With state and territory legislation coming on stream soon that will mirror the Commonwealth legislation, this bill is certainly timely. It becomes necessary, following the agreement of states and territories, to introduce this complementary legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Sports Drug Agency has indicated to me that this coordinated approach will ensure that all athletes competing at international, national, or state levels will now be exposed to drug testing. It will also allow the agency to carry out more drug tests. It is hoped that this will provide an even greater deterrent against the use of performance enhancing drugs, as it will become increasingly difficult to avoid detection. Australia's strong anti-drugs policy should send a message to the sporting world that this country does not support the use of any drugs that enhance performance in sport. The Democrats support this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate on this very important piece of legislation. The points have been made, and made well. I want to pick up a point that has been made. If we are trying to send a message to the community, and particularly to younger Australians, that we do not promote the use of performance enhancing drugs, that message has to be sent consistently and in a fair way, and the legislation ought to reflect the principle that no one competitor in a fair competition can be advantaged over the others.

PARA.TAB: This amendment to the ASDA act allows for testing at all levels of competition in Australia—international, national and local. It also, importantly, allows for a uniform appeals mechanism. So that not only is justice done, but also justice provides athletes who feel that they were not using performance enhancing drugs with an appeals mechanism for them to protect their good names or to see that justice is done in their cases.

It is very important that the principles of fairness in open competition be reflected in a testing mechanism that gives no athletes the opportunity to get away with cheating—which is what performance enhancing drugs really amount to—and provides all athletes equally with access to an appeals mechanism. We can be very encouraged in the extension of this legislation. It builds on the international reputation Australia has established in the area of drugs in sport. I am delighted to thank senators for their support for this legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

I would like to make a particular point with regard to Western Australia, bearing in mind that the costs of disaggregation are supposed to show up and be transparent. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow Senator Panizza and take the opportunity of the tabling of the annual report of the Australian Wheat Board for 1992-93 to make a few comments about the future of wheat. Like Senator Panizza, I would like to congratulate the AWB on the way that it handled the record crop this year.

PARA.TAB: The linchpin to the future of this vital industry is the continuation of the established single desk selling policy for export. It is estimated that single desk selling, which is an advantage to the total Australian economy, is worth between $25 and $30 per tonne. The retention of single desk selling is paramount to Australian wheat growers. It allows the Australian Wheat Board to extract the top market premium for each stratum of the market and for each market. The successful outcome of the Uruguay Round of GATT after years of negotiations is positive news to the wheat industry and it represents an encouraging future in the long term. The main benefits will be the decrease in subsidised United States and European grain entering the world market. The export subsidies for these countries are to be reduced over time by more than 30 per cent—not a panacea but certainly a move in the right direction.

ABARE has estimated that this will increase the value of wheat exports from Australia by about $250 million per year when the reductions are fully implemented over time. Even if these estimates are over-optimistic, we must be confident that the prospects of the industry have been improved. Australian farmers will still see rises and falls in the price of wheat, but now these fluctuations will be decided more by the laws of supply and demand than by the subsidy policies of the United States and the Europeans. The corruption of the market will be reduced, and that will be one less factor outside their control that Australian farmers will have to worry about. That problem will be eventually removed.

This change of direction is important for Australian wheat farmers as, over the past few years, while they have maintained their production of grain, their capital equipment has been running down. Good farmers need good equipment, and it will be a slow process to re-equip. But it has a greater chance of happening now. The Europeans, on the other hand, are much better capitalised with new equipment which will take a significant time to run down. Their potential to maintain production for an extended period of reduced returns is still very high. This could significantly delay the advantages to Australian grain growers. The EEC and the US have also been engaged in significant set-aside programs for their grain production. This has had the effect of taking a large acreage out of production and this land could quite easily enter production again.

The challenge for wheat farmers now is how to react to the changing environment. Knowing Australian farmers as I do, I am sure they will equip themselves very well. The priorities of Australian governments, industry associations, unions and the community generally must be directed to trade access and international competitiveness if Australian employment needs and debt repayment targets are to be met. I commend the AWB on the job it has done this year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak very briefly on the current 24-hour rolling strike in the coal industry which commenced last night. The government has failed to address the underlying cause of the coal industry's problems, although Senator Collins acknowledged the stupidity of this industrial dispute in the Senate today. It is now time for the government, and especially the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Brereton, to outline a coal industry industrial relations reform package to provide a boost for this important industry.

PARA.TAB: Coal is Australia's biggest single commodity export earner and represents one of the more advanced industries as far as technology is concerned. Ironically, however, the industrial relations system that rules the coal industry is outdated and inefficient. It is governed by its own industry specific industrial relations system which operates outside the current mainstream of industrial relations arrangements.

The Coal Industry Tribunal is a one-man board which, in conjunction with the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission and other lesser tribunals in Queensland and Tasmania, acts with virtually the same powers as the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The tribunal came into existence in 1946 at a time when coal production was focused entirely on domestic consumption. It has no place, or very little place, in 1994. This industry has undergone dramatic changes, and the tribunal is still stuck somewhere back in the 1940s.

The level of industrial disputes in the coal sector remains significantly above the national average. In 1988, which is a couple of years ago I know, the number of days lost to industrial disputes per 1,000 employees was 15,548. It is now 2,970 per 1,000 workers. That is a remarkable improvement, I guess, but to put this in perspective it should be compared with an all industry Australian average of just 158 days per 1,000 employees.

In another context the coalmining sector accounts for 0.3 per cent of the work force, but in 1991-92 it accounted for a huge 23 per cent of all industrial relations disputes. Last September's strike—a forerunner to the strike going on now—over BHP coal contract prices illustrated perfectly the problems of the coal sector's industrial relations system.

The Coal Industry Tribunal was powerless to control the United Mine Workers Federation of Australia. The union flagrantly disregarded the one-man tribunal. Before various companies used the section 45D remedies, and before injunctions requiring a return to work were issued, five days of production and $170 million worth of exports were lost, and a reputation of industrial instability was confirmed.

As of last night the industry has again been thrown into a series of rolling stoppages, estimated to cost $1 million per hour, which is $24 million per day in lost production nationwide. This action particularly impacts on the Hunter Valley, an area that is economically crucial to this nation.

Let me make one thing clear. The current strike action cannot overturn the new contract arrangements which have been forced onto producers by shrinking demands from Japanese steel mills. This strike action only places jobs at risk and robs us of the opportunity to have mines maintain their labour forces at current levels.

The coalmining sector is further weakened by every strike such as this, and it makes it all the more difficult to keep up with cutthroat competition from countries such as Canada, which is setting the price on this occasion. Under the present coal sector industrial relations system, neither the industry nor the work force can fight these poor prices and foreign competitors, however upset they might be. Importantly, from an industry perspective, coal industry earnings have totally outstripped industry productivity growth. These sorts of trends kill coal producers, and this problem has stuck with the coal industry for a very long time.

It is not only the coal companies that would benefit from the industry's antiquated industrial relations system being absorbed into the national industry; it would be all of us. The security of employment in the industry and future job growth would be enhanced. The Coal Industry Tribunal can do nothing to lock in labour productivity growth. The last three major studies of the coal industry—namely, the Hancock report of 1983, the Niland report of 1989 and the Industry Commission study of 1991—have all recommended that the Coal Industry Tribunal be abolished.

This essential industry will be one that continues to drag us out of recession. It deserves an industrial relations system to match its national importance. In the meantime, the coal union should realise that its strike action is, regrettably, counterproductive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a very brief comment in the light of Minister Ray's comments on the possible closing of the Nurrungar base in Australia. The Canberra Times reported on 16 July 1993 that a defence department spokesperson said that Australia and the United States were committed to operating the Nurrungar satellite station for some time to come, that a new system—the follow-on early warning system—would replace its functions. Adding a word of caution, the Australian reported that the follow-on early warning system was unlikely to be operational this century and that funding was yet to be confirmed.

PARA.TAB: But later, in October, Defense News reported that, after 11 years of effort costing more than $US550 million, the laser link system is about to be trashed. Developed and built by McDonnell Douglas, the program was to replace the link-ups provided through ground stations by directly linking the satellites themselves. The link was initially requested by the US air force because it wanted freedom from relying on nations like Australia. Now it realises that this `freedom' will make the new defence support program missile warning satellites cost far too much for Pentagon budgets.
Development and testing was supposedly completed in April 1984, and contracts worth $US380 million were given to build eight laser links. In September last year, a US air force spokesperson stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We have since run into technical problems during production.

The laser devices are being delivered months after schedule, are failing in testing and are being returned to McDonnell Douglas, which then has to announce to its shareholders that it lost $US11 million of its own funds spent on the program.

PARA.TAB: Well, can it ever happen? The US government has already wasted heaps of money on the failing program in a time when US voters are less warmed by huge military budgets. The technology does not exist yet. Probably the biggest crunch for the laser links is shareholder dissatisfaction, for without their capital and enthusiasm further development of a Nurrungar replacement will cease.

Are the minister's comments out of step with the realities of developing such an expensive and problem-ridden set of satellites? Is it that the United States has decided that it no longer requires this kind of information gathering? We would like to think so. If that is the case, let us have further information about what decisions are made on our soil. If there is no basis to the comment, why was the comment made?
